<p id="mwEA">The <b id="mwEQ">cat</b> (<i id="mwEg"><b id="mwEw">Felis catus</b></i>) is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Domestication_of_the_cat" title="Domestication of the cat" id="mwFA">domestic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Species" title="Species" id="mwFQ">species</a> of small <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivorous" title="Carnivorous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwFg">carnivorous</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal" title="Mammal" id="mwFw">mammal</a>.<sup about="#mwt45" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Linnaeus1758_1-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Linnaeus1758"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Linnaeus1758-1"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Linnaeus1758-1" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" id="mwGA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwGQ">[1]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt49" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3fc_2-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MSW3fc"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-MSW3fc-2"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-MSW3fc-2" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mwGg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwGw">[2]</span></a></sup> It is the only domesticated species in the family <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Felidae" title="Felidae" id="mwHA">Felidae</a> and is commonly referred to as the <b id="mwHQ">domestic cat</b> or <b id="mwHg">house cat</b> to distinguish it from the wild members of the family.<sup about="#mwt53" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Clutton-Brock1999_4-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Clutton-Brock1999"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Clutton-Brock1999-4"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Clutton-Brock1999-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 4;" id="mwHw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwIA">[4]</span></a></sup> Cats are commonly kept as house pets but can also be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Farm_cat" title="Farm cat" id="mwIQ">farm cats</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feral_cat" title="Feral cat" id="mwIg">feral cats</a>; the feral cat ranges freely and avoids human contact.<sup about="#mwt57" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Liberg_al2014_5-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Liberg_al2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Liberg_al2014-5"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Liberg_al2014-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 5;" id="mwIw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwJA">[5]</span></a></sup> Domestic cats are valued by humans for companionship and their ability to kill <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mwJQ">rodents</a>. About 60 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_breeds" title="Cat breeds" class="mw-redirect" id="mwJg">cat breeds</a> are recognized by various <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_registries" title="Cat registries" class="mw-redirect" id="mwJw">cat registries</a>.<sup about="#mwt61" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Driscoll_al2009_6-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Driscoll_al2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Driscoll_al2009-6"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Driscoll_al2009-6" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 6;" id="mwKA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwKQ">[6]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwKg">The cat is similar in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_anatomy" title="Cat anatomy" id="mwKw">anatomy</a> to the other felid species: it has a strong flexible body, quick <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reflexes" title="Reflexes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwLA">reflexes</a>, sharp teeth, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retractable_claws" title="Retractable claws" class="mw-redirect" id="mwLQ">retractable claws</a> adapted to killing small prey. Its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Night_vision" title="Night vision" id="mwLg">night vision</a> and sense of smell are well developed. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_communication" title="Cat communication" id="mwLw">Cat communication</a> includes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_communication" title="Animal communication" id="mwMA">vocalizations</a> like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meow" title="Meow" id="mwMQ">meowing</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purr" title="Purr" id="mwMg">purring</a>, trilling, hissing, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Growling" title="Growling" id="mwMw">growling</a>, and grunting as well as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_body_language" title="Cat body language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwNA">cat-specific body language</a>. Although the cat is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Social_species" title="Social species" class="mw-redirect" id="mwNQ">social species</a>, it is a solitary hunter. As a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Predator" title="Predator" class="mw-redirect" id="mwNg">predator</a>, it is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crepuscular" title="Crepuscular" class="mw-redirect" id="mwNw">crepuscular</a>, i.e. most active at dawn and dusk. It can hear sounds too faint or too high in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Frequency" title="Frequency" id="mwOA">frequency</a> for human ears, such as those made by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mice" title="Mice" class="mw-redirect" id="mwOQ">mice</a> and other small mammals.<sup about="#mwt67" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Moelk1944_7-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Moelk1944"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Moelk1944-7"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Moelk1944-7" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwOg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwOw">[7]</span></a></sup> It also secretes and perceives <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pheromones" title="Pheromones" class="mw-redirect" id="mwPA">pheromones</a>.<sup about="#mwt71" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bland1979_8-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bland1979"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bland1979-8"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bland1979-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 8;" id="mwPQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwPg">[8]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwPw">Female domestic cats can have kittens from spring to late autumn, with litter sizes often ranging from two to five kittens.<sup about="#mwt77" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nutter2004_9-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nutter2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Nutter2004-9"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Nutter2004-9" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" id="mwQA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwQQ">[9]</span></a></sup> Domestic cats are bred and shown at events as registered <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pedigreed_cat" title="Pedigreed cat" class="mw-redirect" id="mwQg">pedigreed cats</a>, a hobby known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_fancy" title="Cat fancy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwQw">cat fancy</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_population_control" title="Animal population control" class="mw-redirect" id="mwRA">Population control</a> of cats may be achieved<!--"effect" is correct, not "affect".  see https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/effect#Verb--> by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spaying" title="Spaying" class="mw-redirect" id="mwRQ">spaying</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neutering" title="Neutering" id="mwRg">neutering</a>, but their proliferation and the abandonment of pets has resulted in large numbers of feral cats worldwide, contributing to the extinction of entire bird, mammal, and reptile species.<sup about="#mwt81" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Rochlitz_10-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Rochlitz"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Rochlitz-10"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Rochlitz-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" id="mwRw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwSA">[10]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwSQ">It was long thought that cat domestication began in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt" id="mwSg">ancient Egypt</a>, where <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cats_in_ancient_Egypt" title="Cats in ancient Egypt" id="mwSw">cats were venerated</a> from around 3100 BC,<sup about="#mwt88" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-11" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-11"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-11" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwTA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwTQ">[11]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt92" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-12" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-12"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 12;" id="mwTg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwTw">[12]</span></a></sup> but recent advances in archaeology and genetics have shown that their domestication occurred in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Western_Asia" title="Western Asia" id="mwUA">Western Asia</a> around 7500 BC.<sup about="#mwt96" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007_13-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007-13"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007-13" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 13;" id="mwUQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwUg">[13]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwUw"><span about="#mwt104" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"As of","href":"./Template:As_of"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2021"},"post":{"wt":","}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwVA">As of 2021</span><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt104"></span><span about="#mwt104">,</span><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;" about="#mwt104"><a rel="mw:ExtLink" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cat&amp;action=edit" class="external text"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>update<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></sup><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt104"></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements_from_2021" about="#mwt104"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements" about="#mwt104" id="mwVQ"/> there were an estimated 220 million owned and 480<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwVg"> </span>million stray cats in the world.<sup about="#mwt116" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-14" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-14"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-14" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 14;" id="mwVw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwWA">[14]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt120" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-15" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-15"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-15" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 15;" id="mwWQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwWg">[15]</span></a></sup> <span about="#mwt107" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"As of","href":"./Template:As_of"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2017"},"post":{"wt":","}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwWw">As of 2017</span><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt107"></span><span about="#mwt107">,</span><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;" about="#mwt107"><a rel="mw:ExtLink" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cat&amp;action=edit" class="external text"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>update<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></sup><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt107"></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements_from_2017" about="#mwt107"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements" about="#mwt107" id="mwXA"/> the domestic cat was the second most popular pet in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./United_States" title="United States" id="mwXQ">United States</a>, with 95.6<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwXg"> </span>million cats owned<sup about="#mwt124" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-16" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-16"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-16" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 16;" id="mwXw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwYA">[16]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt128" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-17" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-17"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-17" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 17;" id="mwYQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwYg">[17]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt132" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-statistacats_18-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"statistacats"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-statistacats-18"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-statistacats-18" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 18;" id="mwYw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwZA">[18]</span></a></sup> and around 42 million households owning at least one cat.<sup about="#mwt136" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-19" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-19"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-19" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 19;" id="mwZQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwZg">[19]</span></a></sup> In the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom" id="mwZw">United Kingdom</a>, 26% of adults have a cat, with an estimated population of 10.9<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwaA"> </span>million pet cats <span about="#mwt110" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"As of","href":"./Template:As_of"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2020"},"lc":{"wt":"y"},"post":{"wt":"."}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwaQ">as of 2020</span><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt110"></span><span about="#mwt110">.</span><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;" about="#mwt110"><a rel="mw:ExtLink" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cat&amp;action=edit" class="external text"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span>update<span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></a></sup><span typeof="mw:Nowiki" about="#mwt110"></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements_from_2020" about="#mwt110"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements" about="#mwt110" id="mwag"/><sup about="#mwt140" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-20" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-20"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-20" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 20;" id="mwaw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwbA">[20]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="1" id="mwbQ"><h2 id="Etymology_and_naming">Etymology and naming</h2>
<p id="mwbg">The origin of the English word <i id="mwbw">cat</i>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Old_English" title="Old English" id="mwcA">Old English</a> <span title="Old English (ca. 450-1100)-language text" about="#mwt145" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ang"},"2":{"wt":"catt"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwcQ"><i lang="ang">catt</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Old_English_(ca._450-1100)-language_text" about="#mwt145" id="mwcg"/>, is thought to be the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Latin" title="Late Latin" id="mwcw">Late Latin</a> word <span title="Latin-language text" about="#mwt146" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"la"},"2":{"wt":"cattus"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwdA"><i lang="la">cattus</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Latin-language_text" about="#mwt146" id="mwdQ"/>, which was first used at the beginning of the 6th century.<sup about="#mwt160" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-21" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-21"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-21" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 21;" id="mwdg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwdw">[21]</span></a></sup> It was suggested that <span title="Latin-language text" about="#mwt147" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"la"},"2":{"wt":"cattus"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mweA"><i lang="la">cattus</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Latin-language_text" about="#mwt147" id="mweQ"/> is derived from an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Egyptian_language" title="Egyptian language" id="mweg">Egyptian</a> precursor of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coptic_language" title="Coptic language" id="mwew">Coptic</a> <span title="Coptic-language text" about="#mwt148" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"cop"},"2":{"wt":"[[wikt:ϣⲁⲩ|ϣⲁⲩ]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwfA"><span lang="cop"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ϣⲁⲩ" title="wikt:ϣⲁⲩ" class="extiw">ϣⲁⲩ</a></span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Coptic-language_text" about="#mwt148" id="mwfQ"/> <span title="Coptic-language text" about="#mwt149" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"cop-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"šau"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwfg"><i lang="cop-Latn">šau</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Coptic-language_text" about="#mwt149" id="mwfw"/>, 'tomcat', or its feminine form suffixed with <span title="Ancient Egyptian-language text" about="#mwt150" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"egy-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"-t"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwgA"><i lang="egy-Latn">-t</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Egyptian-language_text" about="#mwt150" id="mwgQ"/>.<sup about="#mwt164" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-22" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-22"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-22" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 22;" id="mwgg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwgw">[22]</span></a></sup> The Late Latin word may be derived from another <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Afro-Asiatic" title="Afro-Asiatic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwhA">Afro-Asiatic</a><sup about="#mwt168" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-23" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-23"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-23" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 23;" id="mwhQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwhg">[23]</span></a></sup> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nilo-Saharan" title="Nilo-Saharan" class="mw-redirect" id="mwhw">Nilo-Saharan</a> language. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nubian_languages" title="Nubian languages" id="mwiA">Nubian</a> word <span title="Nubian languages collective text" about="#mwt151" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"nub"},"2":{"wt":"kaddîska"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwiQ"><i lang="nub">kaddîska</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_text_in_Nubian_languages" about="#mwt151" id="mwig"/> 'wildcat' and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nobiin_language" title="Nobiin language" id="mwiw">Nobiin</a> <span title="Nubian languages collective text" about="#mwt152" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"nub"},"2":{"wt":"kadīs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwjA"><i lang="nub">kadīs</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_text_in_Nubian_languages" about="#mwt152" id="mwjQ"/> are possible sources or cognates.<sup about="#mwt172" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-24" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-24"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-24" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 24;" id="mwjg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwjw">[24]</span></a></sup> The Nubian word may be a loan from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arabic_language" title="Arabic language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwkA">Arabic</a> <span title="Arabic-language text" about="#mwt153" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ar"},"2":{"wt":"قَطّ{{lrm}}"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwkQ"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl">قَطّ<span typeof="mw:Entity">‎</span></span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Arabic-language_text" about="#mwt153" id="mwkg"/> <span title="Arabic-language text" about="#mwt154" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ar-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"qaṭṭ"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwkw"><i lang="ar-Latn">qaṭṭ</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Arabic-language_text" about="#mwt154" id="mwlA"/> ~ <span title="Arabic-language text" about="#mwt155" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ar"},"2":{"wt":"قِطّ"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwlQ"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl">قِطّ</span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Arabic-language_text" about="#mwt155" id="mwlg"/> <span title="Arabic-language text" about="#mwt156" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ar-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"qiṭṭ"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwlw"><i lang="ar-Latn">qiṭṭ</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Arabic-language_text" about="#mwt156" id="mwmA"/>.</p>

<p id="mwmQ">However, it is "equally likely that the forms might derive from an ancient Germanic word, imported into Latin and thence to Greek and to Syriac and Arabic".<sup about="#mwt181" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-25" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-25"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-25" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mwmg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwmw">[25]</span></a></sup> The word may be derived from Germanic and Northern European languages, and ultimately be borrowed from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages" id="mwnA">Uralic</a>, cf. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Northern_Sami_language" title="Northern Sami language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwnQ">Northern Sami</a> <span title="Northern Sami-language text" about="#mwt175" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"se"},"2":{"wt":"gáđfi"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwng"><i lang="se">gáđfi</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Northern_Sami-language_text" about="#mwt175" id="mwnw"/>, 'female <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stoat" title="Stoat" id="mwoA">stoat</a>', and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language" id="mwoQ">Hungarian</a> <span title="Hungarian-language text" about="#mwt176" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"hu"},"2":{"wt":"hölgy"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwog"><i lang="hu">hölgy</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Hungarian-language_text" about="#mwt176" id="mwow"/>, 'lady, female stoat'; from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Proto-Uralic_language" title="Proto-Uralic language" id="mwpA">Proto-Uralic</a> <span title="uncoded-language text" about="#mwt177" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"mis"},"2":{"wt":"*käďwä"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwpQ"><span typeof="mw:Entity">*</span><i lang="mis">käďwä</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_uncoded-language_text" about="#mwt177" id="mwpg"/>, 'female (of a furred animal)'.<sup about="#mwt185" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-26" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-26"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-26" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mwpw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwqA">[26]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwqQ">The English <i id="mwqg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/puss#English" title="wikt:puss" class="extiw" id="mwqw">puss</a></i>, extended as <i id="mwrA">pussy</i> and <i id="mwrQ">pussycat</i>, is attested from the 16th century and may have been introduced from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dutch_language" title="Dutch language" id="mwrg">Dutch</a> <span title="Dutch-language text" about="#mwt188" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"nl"},"2":{"wt":"poes"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwrw"><i lang="nl">poes</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Dutch-language_text" about="#mwt188" id="mwsA"/> or from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Low_German" title="Low German" id="mwsQ">Low German</a> <span title="Low German-language text" about="#mwt189" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"nds"},"2":{"wt":"puuskatte"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwsg"><i lang="nds">puuskatte</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Low_German-language_text" about="#mwt189" id="mwsw"/>, related to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Swedish_language" title="Swedish language" id="mwtA">Swedish</a> <span title="Swedish-language text" about="#mwt190" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"sv"},"2":{"wt":"kattepus"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwtQ"><i lang="sv">kattepus</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Swedish-language_text" about="#mwt190" id="mwtg"/>, or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language" id="mwtw">Norwegian</a> <span title="Norwegian-language text" about="#mwt191" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"no"},"2":{"wt":"pus"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwuA"><i lang="no">pus</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Norwegian-language_text" about="#mwt191" id="mwuQ"/>, <span title="Norwegian-language text" about="#mwt192" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"no"},"2":{"wt":"pusekatt"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwug"><i lang="no">pusekatt</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Norwegian-language_text" about="#mwt192" id="mwuw"/>. Similar forms exist in Lithuanian <span title="Lithuanian-language text" about="#mwt193" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"lt"},"2":{"wt":"puižė"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwvA"><i lang="lt">puižė</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Lithuanian-language_text" about="#mwt193" id="mwvQ"/> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Irish_language" title="Irish language" id="mwvg">Irish</a> <span title="Irish-language text" about="#mwt194" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ga"},"2":{"wt":"puisín"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwvw"><i lang="ga">puisín</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Irish-language_text" about="#mwt194" id="mwwA"/> or <span title="Irish-language text" about="#mwt195" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ga"},"2":{"wt":"puiscín"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwwQ"><i lang="ga">puiscín</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Irish-language_text" about="#mwt195" id="mwwg"/>. The etymology of this word is unknown, but it may have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Onomatopoeia" title="Onomatopoeia" id="mwww">arisen from a sound</a> used to attract a cat.<sup about="#mwt199" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-27" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-27"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-27" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mwxA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwxQ">[27]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt203" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Gramercy_Unabridged_28-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Gramercy Unabridged"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Gramercy_Unabridged-28"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Gramercy_Unabridged-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 28;" id="mwxg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwxw">[28]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwyA">A male cat is called a <i id="mwyQ">tom</i> or <i id="mwyg">tomcat</i><sup about="#mwt214" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-29" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-29"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-29" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;" id="mwyw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwzA">[29]</span></a></sup> (or a <i id="mwzQ">gib</i>,<sup about="#mwt218" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-30" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-30"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-30" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 30;" id="mwzg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwzw">[30]</span></a></sup> if <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neutering" title="Neutering" id="mw0A">neutered</a>). A female is called a <i id="mw0Q">queen</i><sup about="#mwt222" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-31" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-31"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-31" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 31;" id="mw0g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw0w">[31]</span></a></sup> (or a <i id="mw1A">molly</i>,<sup about="#mwt226" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-32" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-32"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-32" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 32;" id="mw1Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw1g">[32]</span></a></sup><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Accuracy_disputes_from_November_2022" about="#mwt210" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"ugc","href":"./Template:Ugc"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"November 2022"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw1w"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template " style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt210" id="mw2A"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:UGC" title="Wikipedia:UGC" class="mw-redirect"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on a user-generated source. (November 2022)">user-generated source?</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> if <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spaying" title="Spaying" class="mw-redirect" id="mw2Q">spayed</a>), especially in a cat-breeding context. A juvenile cat is referred to as a <i id="mw2g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kitten" title="Kitten" id="mw2w">kitten</a></i>. In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Modern_English" title="Early Modern English" id="mw3A">Early Modern English</a>, the word <i id="mw3Q">kitten</i> was interchangeable with the now-obsolete word <i id="mw3g">catling</i>.<sup about="#mwt230" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-33" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-33"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-33" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 33;" id="mw3w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw4A">[33]</span></a></sup> A group of cats can be referred to as a <i id="mw4Q">clowder</i> or a <i id="mw4g">glaring</i>.<sup about="#mwt234" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-34" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-34"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-34" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 34;" id="mw4w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw5A">[34]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="2" id="mw5Q"><h2 id="Taxonomy">Taxonomy</h2>
<p id="mw5g">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scientific_name" title="Scientific name" class="mw-redirect" id="mw5w">scientific name</a> <i id="mw6A">Felis catus</i> was proposed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus" id="mw6Q">Carl Linnaeus</a> in 1758 for a domestic cat.<sup about="#mwt240" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Linnaeus1758_1-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Linnaeus1758"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Linnaeus1758-1" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" id="mw6g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw6w">[1]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt241" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3fc_2-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MSW3fc"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-MSW3fc-2" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mw7A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw7Q">[2]</span></a></sup> <i id="mw7g">Felis catus domesticus</i> was proposed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Johann_Christian_Polycarp_Erxleben" title="Johann Christian Polycarp Erxleben" id="mw7w">Johann Christian Polycarp Erxleben</a> in 1777.<sup about="#mwt242" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Erxleben_3-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Erxleben"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Erxleben-3" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mw8A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw8Q">[3]</span></a></sup> <i id="mw8g">Felis daemon</i> proposed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Konstantin_Satunin" title="Konstantin Satunin" id="mw8w">Konstantin Satunin</a> in 1904 was a black cat from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Transcaucasus" title="Transcaucasus" class="mw-redirect" id="mw9A">Transcaucasus</a>, later identified as a domestic cat.<sup about="#mwt246" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-35" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-35"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-35" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 35;" id="mw9Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw9g">[35]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt250" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-36" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-36"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-36" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 36;" id="mw9w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw-A">[36]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mw-Q">In 2003, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./International_Commission_on_Zoological_Nomenclature" title="International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature" id="mw-g">International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature</a> ruled that the domestic cat is a distinct species, namely <i id="mw-w">Felis catus</i>.<sup about="#mwt256" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ICZN_37-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ICZN"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ICZN-37"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-ICZN-37" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 37;" id="mw_A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw_Q">[37]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt260" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-38" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-38"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-38" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 38;" id="mw_g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw_w">[38]</span></a></sup>
In 2007, it was considered a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Subspecies" title="Subspecies" id="mwAQA">subspecies</a>, <i id="mwAQE">F. silvestris catus</i>, of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./European_wildcat" title="European wildcat" id="mwAQI">European wildcat</a> (<i id="mwAQM">F. silvestris</i>) following results of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetic" title="Phylogenetic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAQQ">phylogenetic</a> research.<sup about="#mwt267" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Driscoll_39-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Driscoll"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Driscoll-39"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Driscoll-39" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 39;" id="mwAQU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQY">[39]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt271" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3fs_40-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MSW3fs"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-MSW3fs-40"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-MSW3fs-40" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwAQc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQg">[40]</span></a></sup> In 2017, the IUCN Cat Classification Taskforce followed the recommendation of the ICZN in regarding the domestic cat as a distinct species, <i id="mwAQk">Felis catus</i>.<sup about="#mwt275" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-41" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-41"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 41;" id="mwAQo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQs">[41]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="3" id="mwAQw"><h2 id="Evolution">Evolution</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt276" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Felidae#Evolution"},"l1":{"wt":"Cat evolution"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAQ0"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt276" id="mwAQ4">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Felidae#Evolution" title="Felidae">Cat evolution</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAQ8"><a href="./File:Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwARA"><img resource="./File:Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png/220px-Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="585" data-file-height="678" data-file-type="bitmap" height="255" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png/330px-Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png/440px-Wild-domestic-hybrid_cat_skulls.png 2x" id="mwARE"/></a><figcaption id="mwARI">Skulls of a wildcat (top left), a housecat (top right), and a hybrid between the two. (bottom center)</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwARM">The domestic cat is a member of the Felidae, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)" id="mwARQ">family</a> that had a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Common_ancestor" title="Common ancestor" class="mw-redirect" id="mwARU">common ancestor</a> about 10–15<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwARY"> </span>million years ago.<sup about="#mwt283" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson_1997_42-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Johnson 1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Johnson_1997-42"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Johnson_1997-42" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 42;" id="mwARc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwARg">[42]</span></a></sup>
The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genus_(biology)" title="Genus (biology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwARk">genus</a> <i id="mwARo">Felis</i> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_divergence" title="Genetic divergence" id="mwARs">diverged</a> from other Felidae around 6–7<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwARw"> </span>million years ago.<sup about="#mwt292" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson_43-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Johnson"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Johnson-43"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Johnson-43" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 43;" id="mwAR0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAR4">[43]</span></a></sup> Results of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetic" title="Phylogenetic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAR8">phylogenetic</a> research confirm that the wild <i id="mwASA">Felis</i> species evolved through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sympatric_speciation" title="Sympatric speciation" id="mwASE">sympatric</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parapatric_speciation" title="Parapatric speciation" id="mwASI">parapatric speciation</a>, whereas the domestic cat evolved through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artificial_selection" title="Artificial selection" class="mw-redirect" id="mwASM">artificial selection</a>.<sup about="#mwt296" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mattern_44-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mattern"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Mattern-44"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Mattern-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 44;" id="mwASQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASU">[44]</span></a></sup> The domesticated cat and its closest wild ancestor are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diploid" title="Diploid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwASY">diploid</a> and both possess 38 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chromosome" title="Chromosome" id="mwASc">chromosomes</a><sup about="#mwt300" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nie_2002_45-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nie 2002"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Nie_2002-45"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Nie_2002-45" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 45;" id="mwASg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASk">[45]</span></a></sup> and roughly 20,000 genes.<sup about="#mwt304" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid17975172_46-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid17975172"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid17975172-46"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-pmid17975172-46" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 46;" id="mwASo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASs">[46]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leopard_cat" title="Leopard cat" id="mwASw">leopard cat</a> (<i id="mwAS0">Prionailurus bengalensis</i>) was <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tamed" title="Tamed" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAS4">tamed</a> independently in China around 5500 BC. This line of partially domesticated cats leaves no trace in the domestic cat populations of today.<sup about="#mwt308" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-47" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-47"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-47" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 47;" id="mwAS8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATA">[47]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="4" id="mwATE"><h3 id="Domestication">Domestication</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt309" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Domestication of the cat"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATI"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt309" id="mwATM">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Domestication_of_the_cat" title="Domestication of the cat">Domestication of the cat</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwATQ"><a href="./File:Tomb_of_Nakht_(7).jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwATU"><img resource="./File:Tomb_of_Nakht_(7).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg/220px-Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="761" data-file-height="828" data-file-type="bitmap" height="239" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg/330px-Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg/440px-Tomb_of_Nakht_%287%29.jpg 2x" id="mwATY"/></a><figcaption id="mwATc">A cat eating a fish under a chair, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mural" title="Mural" id="mwATg">mural</a> in an Egyptian tomb dating to the 15th century BC</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwATk">The earliest known indication for the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taming" title="Taming" class="mw-redirect" id="mwATo">taming</a> of an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./African_wildcat" title="African wildcat" id="mwATs">African wildcat</a> (<i id="mwATw">F. lybica</i>) was <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Excavation_(archaeology)" title="Excavation (archaeology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAT0">excavated</a> close by a human <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neolithic" title="Neolithic" id="mwAT4">Neolithic</a> grave in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shillourokambos" title="Shillourokambos" id="mwAT8">Shillourokambos</a>, southern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cyprus" title="Cyprus" id="mwAUA">Cyprus</a>, dating to about 7500–7200 BC. Since there is no evidence of native mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fauna" title="Fauna" id="mwAUE">fauna</a> on Cyprus, the inhabitants of this Neolithic village most likely brought the cat and other wild mammals to the island from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_East" title="Middle East" id="mwAUI">Middle Eastern</a> mainland.<sup about="#mwt319" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Vigne_al2004_48-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Vigne_al2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Vigne_al2004-48"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Vigne_al2004-48" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 48;" id="mwAUM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUQ">[48]</span></a></sup> Scientists therefore assume that African wildcats were attracted to early human settlements in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fertile_Crescent" title="Fertile Crescent" id="mwAUU">Fertile Crescent</a> by rodents, in particular the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./House_mouse" title="House mouse" id="mwAUY">house mouse</a> (<i id="mwAUc">Mus musculus</i>), and were tamed by Neolithic farmers. This <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mutualism_(biology)" title="Mutualism (biology)" id="mwAUg">mutual</a> relationship between early farmers and tamed cats lasted thousands of years. As <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agricultural_practices" title="Agricultural practices" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAUk">agricultural practices</a> spread, so did tame and domesticated cats.<sup about="#mwt320" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007_13-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-DriscollMenotti-Raymond2007-13" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 13;" id="mwAUo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUs">[13]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt321" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Driscoll_al2009_6-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Driscoll_al2009"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Driscoll_al2009-6" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 6;" id="mwAUw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAU0">[6]</span></a></sup> Wildcats of Egypt contributed to the maternal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gene_pool" title="Gene pool" id="mwAU4">gene pool</a> of the domestic cat at a later time.<sup about="#mwt325" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OttoniVan_Neer2017_49-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OttoniVan Neer2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-OttoniVan_Neer2017-49"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-OttoniVan_Neer2017-49" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwAU8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVA">[49]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAVE">The earliest known evidence for the occurrence of the domestic cat in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greece" title="Greece" id="mwAVI">Greece</a> dates to around 1200 BC. Greek, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia" id="mwAVM">Phoenician</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carthaginia" title="Carthaginia" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVQ">Carthaginian</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Etrusca" title="Etrusca" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVU">Etruscan</a> traders introduced domestic cats to southern Europe.<sup about="#mwt333" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Faure2009_50-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Faure2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Faure2009-50"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Faure2009-50" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwAVY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVc">[50]</span></a></sup> During the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire" id="mwAVg">Roman Empire</a> they were introduced to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Corsica" title="Corsica" id="mwAVk">Corsica</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sardinia" title="Sardinia" id="mwAVo">Sardinia</a> before the beginning of the 1st millennium.<sup about="#mwt337" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Vigne1992_51-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Vigne1992"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Vigne1992-51"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Vigne1992-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 51;" id="mwAVs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVw">[51]</span></a></sup> By the 5th century BC, they were familiar animals around settlements in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia" id="mwAV0">Magna Graecia</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Etruria" title="Etruria" id="mwAV4">Etruria</a>.<sup about="#mwt341" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-52" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-52"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-52" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 52;" id="mwAV8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWA">[52]</span></a></sup> By the end of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century, the Egyptian domestic cat lineage had arrived in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea" id="mwAWE">Baltic Sea</a> port in northern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Germany" title="Germany" id="mwAWI">Germany</a>.<sup about="#mwt342" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OttoniVan_Neer2017_49-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OttoniVan Neer2017"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-OttoniVan_Neer2017-49" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwAWM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWQ">[49]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAWU">During domestication, cats have undergone only minor changes in anatomy and behavior, and they are still capable of surviving in the wild. Several natural behaviors and characteristics of wildcats may have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Preadaptation" title="Preadaptation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAWY">pre-adapted</a> them for domestication as pets. These traits include their small size, social nature, obvious body language, love of play, and high intelligence. Captive <i id="mwAWc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leopardus" title="Leopardus" id="mwAWg">Leopardus</a></i> cats may also display affectionate behavior toward humans but were not domesticated.<sup about="#mwt350" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-CameronBeaumont_53-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"CameronBeaumont"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-CameronBeaumont-53"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-CameronBeaumont-53" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 53;" id="mwAWk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWo">[53]</span></a></sup> House cats often mate with feral cats.<sup about="#mwt354" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bradshaw1999_54-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bradshaw1999"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bradshaw1999-54"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bradshaw1999-54" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 54;" id="mwAWs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWw">[54]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Felid_hybrid#Domestic_cat_and_hybridization" title="Felid hybrid" id="mwAW0">Hybridisation between domestic and other Felinae species</a> is also possible, producing hybrids such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kellas_cat" title="Kellas cat" id="mwAW4">Kellas cat</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scotland" title="Scotland" id="mwAW8">Scotland</a>.<sup about="#mwt358" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-55" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-55"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-55" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;" id="mwAXA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXE">[55]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt359" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Oliveira_56-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Oliveira"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Oliveira-56" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;" id="mwAXI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXM">[56]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAXQ">Development of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_breeds" title="Cat breeds" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAXU">cat breeds</a> started in the mid 19th century.<sup about="#mwt366" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-57" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-57"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-57" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwAXY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXc">[57]</span></a></sup> An analysis of the domestic cat <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genome" title="Genome" id="mwAXg">genome</a> revealed that the ancestral wildcat genome was significantly altered in the process of domestication, as specific <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mutation" title="Mutation" id="mwAXk">mutations</a> were selected to develop cat breeds.<sup about="#mwt370" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-58" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-58"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 58;" id="mwAXo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXs">[58]</span></a></sup> Most breeds are founded on random-bred domestic cats. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity" id="mwAXw">Genetic diversity</a> of these breeds varies between regions, and is lowest in purebred populations, which show more than 20 deleterious <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_disorder" title="Genetic disorder" id="mwAX0">genetic disorders</a>.<sup about="#mwt374" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lipinski_59-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lipinski"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lipinski-59"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Lipinski-59" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;" id="mwAX4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAX8">[59]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="5" id="mwAYA"><h2 id="Characteristics">Characteristics</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt375" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat anatomy"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAYE"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt375" id="mwAYI">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_anatomy" title="Cat anatomy">Cat anatomy</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="6" id="mwAYM"><h3 id="Size">Size</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAYQ"><a href="./File:Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAYU"><img resource="./File:Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg/220px-Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1040" data-file-height="432" data-file-type="drawing" height="91" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg/330px-Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg/440px-Scheme_cat_anatomy.svg.png 2x" id="mwAYY"/></a><figcaption id="mwAYc">Diagram of the general <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anatomy" title="Anatomy" id="mwAYg">anatomy</a> of a male domestic cat</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAYk">The domestic cat has a smaller <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skull" title="Skull" id="mwAYo">skull</a> and shorter bones than the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./European_wildcat" title="European wildcat" id="mwAYs">European wildcat</a>.<sup about="#mwt382" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OConnor_60-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OConnor"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-OConnor-60"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-OConnor-60" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;" id="mwAYw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAY0">[60]</span></a></sup>
It averages about <span about="#mwt384" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"46"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAY4">46</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt384"> </span><span about="#mwt384">cm (18</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt384"> </span><span about="#mwt384">in)</span> in head-to-body length and <span about="#mwt385" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"23"},"2":{"wt":"-"},"3":{"wt":"25"},"4":{"wt":"cm"},"5":{"wt":"in"},"frac":{"wt":"2"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAY8">23–25</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt385"> </span><span about="#mwt385">cm (9–10</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt385"> </span><span about="#mwt385">in)</span> in height, with about <span about="#mwt386" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAZA">30</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt386"> </span><span about="#mwt386">cm (12</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt386"> </span><span about="#mwt386">in)</span> long tails. Males are larger than females.<sup about="#mwt390" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-WCoW_61-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"WCoW"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-WCoW-61"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-WCoW-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwAZE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZI">[61]</span></a></sup>
Adult domestic cats typically weigh between <span about="#mwt392" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4"},"2":{"wt":"and"},"3":{"wt":"5"},"4":{"wt":"kg"},"5":{"wt":"lb"},"6":{"wt":"0"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAZM">4 and 5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt392"> </span><span about="#mwt392">kg (9 and 11</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt392"> </span><span about="#mwt392">lb)</span>.<sup about="#mwt393" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mattern_44-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mattern"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Mattern-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 44;" id="mwAZQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZU">[44]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="7" id="mwAZY"><h3 id="Skeleton">Skeleton</h3>
<p id="mwAZc">Cats have seven <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cervical_vertebrae" title="Cervical vertebrae" id="mwAZg">cervical vertebrae</a> (as do most <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammals" title="Mammals" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAZk">mammals</a>); 13 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thoracic_vertebrae" title="Thoracic vertebrae" id="mwAZo">thoracic vertebrae</a> (humans have 12); seven <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lumbar_vertebrae" title="Lumbar vertebrae" id="mwAZs">lumbar vertebrae</a> (humans have five); three <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sacrum" title="Sacrum" id="mwAZw">sacral vertebrae</a> (as do most mammals, but humans have five); and a variable number of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caudal_vertebrae" title="Caudal vertebrae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAZ0">caudal vertebrae</a> in the tail (humans have only three to five vestigial caudal vertebrae, fused into an internal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coccyx" title="Coccyx" id="mwAZ4">coccyx</a>).<sup about="#mwt402" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Walker_62-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Walker"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Walker-62"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Walker-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;" id="mwAZ8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAaA">[62]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt397" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"11"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAaE"><span title="Page / location: 11"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>11<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> The extra lumbar and thoracic vertebrae account for the cat's spinal mobility and flexibility. Attached to the spine are 13 ribs, the shoulder, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pelvis" title="Pelvis" id="mwAaI">pelvis</a>.<sup about="#mwt403" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Walker_62-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Walker"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Walker-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;" id="mwAaM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAaQ">[62]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt398" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"16"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAaU"><span title="Page / location: 16"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>16<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Unlike human arms, cat forelimbs are attached to the shoulder by free-floating <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clavicle" title="Clavicle" id="mwAaY">clavicle</a> bones which allow them to pass their body through any space into which they can fit their head.<sup about="#mwt407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Gillis_2002_63-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Gillis 2002"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Gillis_2002-63"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Gillis_2002-63" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwAac"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAag">[63]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="8" id="mwAak"><h3 id="Skull">Skull</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAao"><a href="./File:Cat_skull.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAas"><img resource="./File:Cat_skull.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Cat_skull.jpg/220px-Cat_skull.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="818" data-file-height="578" data-file-type="bitmap" height="155" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Cat_skull.jpg/330px-Cat_skull.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Cat_skull.jpg/440px-Cat_skull.jpg 2x" id="mwAaw"/></a><figcaption id="mwAa0">Cat skull</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAa4"><a href="./File:Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAa8"><img resource="./File:Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg/220px-Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="5472" data-file-height="3648" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg/330px-Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg/440px-Cat_yawn_with_exposed_teeth_and_claws.jpg 2x" id="mwAbA"/></a><figcaption id="mwAbE">A cat with exposed teeth and claws</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAbI">The cat skull is unusual among mammals in having very large <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eye_socket" title="Eye socket" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAbM">eye sockets</a> and a powerful specialized jaw.<sup about="#mwt415" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Case_64-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Case"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Case-64"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Case-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAbQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbU">[64]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt411" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"35"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAbY"><span title="Page / location: 35"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>35<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Within the jaw, cats have teeth adapted for killing prey and tearing meat. When it overpowers its prey, a cat delivers a lethal neck bite with its two long <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Canine_tooth" title="Canine tooth" id="mwAbc">canine teeth</a>, inserting them between two of the prey's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebra" title="Vertebra" id="mwAbg">vertebrae</a> and severing its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spinal_cord" title="Spinal cord" id="mwAbk">spinal cord</a>, causing irreversible <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paralysis" title="Paralysis" id="mwAbo">paralysis</a> and death.<sup about="#mwt419" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Smith1992_65-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Smith1992"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Smith1992-65"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Smith1992-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAbs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbw">[65]</span></a></sup> Compared to other felines, domestic cats have narrowly spaced canine teeth relative to the size of their jaw, which is an adaptation to their preferred prey of small rodents, which have small vertebrae.<sup about="#mwt420" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Smith1992_65-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Smith1992"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Smith1992-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAb0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAb4">[65]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAb8">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Premolar" title="Premolar" id="mwAcA">premolar</a> and first <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molar_(tooth)" title="Molar (tooth)" id="mwAcE">molar</a> together compose the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnassial" title="Carnassial" id="mwAcI">carnassial</a> pair on each side of the mouth, which efficiently shears meat into small pieces, like a pair of scissors. These are vital in feeding, since cats' small <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molar_(tooth)" title="Molar (tooth)" id="mwAcM">molars</a> cannot chew food effectively, and cats are largely incapable of mastication.<sup about="#mwt424" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Case_64-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Case"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Case-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAcQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcU">[64]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt423" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"37"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAcY"><span title="Page / location: 37"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>37<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Although cats tend to have better teeth than most humans, with decay generally less likely because of a thicker protective layer of enamel, a less damaging saliva, less retention of food particles between teeth, and a diet mostly devoid of sugar, they are nonetheless subject to occasional tooth loss and infection.<sup about="#mwt428" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Carr1978_66-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Carr1978"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Carr1978-66"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Carr1978-66" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 66;" id="mwAcc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcg">[66]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="9" id="mwAck"><h3 id="Claws">Claws</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAco"><a href="./File:Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAcs"><img resource="./File:Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff/lossless-page1-110px-Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1081" data-file-height="1175" data-file-type="bitmap" height="120" width="110" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff/lossless-page1-165px-Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff/lossless-page1-220px-Shed_domestic_cat_claw_sheaths.tiff.png 2x" id="mwAcw"/></a><figcaption id="mwAc0">Shed claw sheaths</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAc4">Cats have protractible and retractable claws.<sup about="#mwt435" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kitchener2010_67-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kitchener2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kitchener2010-67"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kitchener2010-67" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwAc8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdA">[67]</span></a></sup> In their normal, relaxed position, the claws are sheathed with the skin and fur around the paw's toe pads. This keeps the claws sharp by preventing wear from contact with the ground and allows for the silent stalking of prey. The claws on the forefeet are typically sharper than those on the hindfeet.<sup about="#mwt439" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Armes_1900_68-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Armes 1900"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Armes_1900-68"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Armes_1900-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 68;" id="mwAdE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdI">[68]</span></a></sup> Cats can voluntarily extend their claws on one or more paws. They may extend their claws in hunting or self-defense, climbing, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kneading_(cats)" title="Kneading (cats)" id="mwAdM">kneading</a>, or for extra traction on soft surfaces. Cats shed the outside layer of their claw sheaths when scratching rough surfaces.<sup about="#mwt443" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid19422432_69-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid19422432"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid19422432-69"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-pmid19422432-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAdQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdU">[69]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAdY">Most cats have five claws on their front paws and four on their rear paws. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dewclaw" title="Dewclaw" id="mwAdc">dewclaw</a> is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Proximal" title="Proximal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAdg">proximal</a> to the other claws. More proximally is a protrusion which appears to be a sixth "finger". This special feature of the front paws on the inside of the wrists has no function in normal walking but is thought to be an antiskidding device used while jumping. Some cat breeds are prone to having extra digits ("<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polydactyl_cat" title="Polydactyl cat" id="mwAdk">polydactyly</a>").<sup about="#mwt449" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Danforth1947_70-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Danforth1947"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Danforth1947-70"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Danforth1947-70" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;" id="mwAdo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAds">[70]</span></a></sup> Polydactylous cats occur along North America's northeast coast and in Great Britain.<sup about="#mwt453" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lettice_2008_71-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lettice 2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lettice_2008-71"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Lettice_2008-71" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;" id="mwAdw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAd0">[71]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="10" id="mwAd4"><h3 id="Ambulation">Ambulation</h3>
<p id="mwAd8">The cat is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Digitigrade" title="Digitigrade" id="mwAeA">digitigrade</a>. It walks on the toes, with the bones of the feet making up the lower part of the visible leg.<sup about="#mwt459" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Pocock1917_72-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Pocock1917"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Pocock1917-72"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Pocock1917-72" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 72;" id="mwAeE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeI">[72]</span></a></sup> Unlike most mammals, it uses a "pacing" <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gait" title="Gait" id="mwAeM">gait</a> and moves both legs on one side of the body before the legs on the other side. It registers directly by placing each hind paw close to the track of the corresponding fore paw, minimizing noise and visible tracks. This also provides sure footing for hind paws when navigating rough terrain. As it speeds up from walking to trotting, its gait changes to a "diagonal" gait: The diagonally opposite hind and fore legs move simultaneously.<sup about="#mwt463" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Christensen_2004_73-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Christensen 2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Christensen_2004-73"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Christensen_2004-73" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 73;" id="mwAeQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeU">[73]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="11" id="mwAeY"><h3 id="Balance">Balance</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" data-mw='{"attribs":[["thumbtime",{"txt":"4:00"}],["starttime",{"txt":"3:37"}],["endtime",{"txt":"4:11"}]]}' id="mwAec"><span id="mwAeg"><video poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/220px-seek%3D240-BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" height="165" width="220" resource="./File:BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv" id="mwAek"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv#t=217,251" type='video/ogg; codecs="theora, vorbis"' data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480" data-title="Original Ogg file, 640 × 480 (4.92 Mbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" id="mwAeo"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.120p.vp9.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="160" data-height="120" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" id="mwAes"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.160p.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="214" data-height="160" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" id="mwAew"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.180p.vp9.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="240" data-height="180" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" id="mwAe0"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.240p.vp9.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="320" data-height="240" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" id="mwAe4"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.240p.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="320" data-height="240" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" id="mwAe8"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.360p.vp9.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm;
