codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="480" data-height="360" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" id="mwAfA"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.360p.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="480" data-height="360" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" id="mwAfE"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.480p.vp9.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="640" data-height="480" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" id="mwAfI"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a1/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv/BIOASTRONAUTICS_RESEARCH_Gov.archives.arc.68700.ogv.480p.webm#t=217,251" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="640" data-height="480" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" id="mwAfM"/></video></span><figcaption id="mwAfQ">Comparison of cat righting reflexes in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravity" title="Gravity" id="mwAfU">gravity</a> and zero gravity</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAfY">Most breeds of cat are notably fond of sitting in high places, or <i id="mwAfc">perching</i>. A higher place may serve as a concealed site from which to hunt; domestic cats strike prey by pouncing from a perch such as a tree branch. Another possible explanation is that height gives the cat a better observation point, allowing it to survey its territory. A cat falling from heights of up to <span about="#mwt465" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAfg">3 meters (9.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt465"> </span><span about="#mwt465">ft)</span> can right itself and land on its paws.<sup about="#mwt469" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kent_et_al._2010_74-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kent et al. 2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kent_et_al._2010-74"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kent_et_al._2010-74" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 74;" id="mwAfk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAfo">[74]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAfs">During a fall from a high place, a cat reflexively twists its body and rights itself to land on its feet using its acute sense of balance and flexibility. This reflex is known as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_righting_reflex" title="Cat righting reflex" id="mwAfw">cat righting reflex</a>.<sup about="#mwt477" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-75" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-75"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-75" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;" id="mwAf0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAf4">[75]</span></a></sup> A cat always rights itself in the same way during a fall, if it has enough time to do so, which is the case in falls of <span about="#mwt473" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"90"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"ftin"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAf8">90</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt473"> </span><span about="#mwt473">cm (2</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt473"> </span><span about="#mwt473">ft 11</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt473"> </span><span about="#mwt473">in)</span> or more.<sup about="#mwt482" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nguyen_1998_76-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nguyen 1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Nguyen_1998-76"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Nguyen_1998-76" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 76;" id="mwAgA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgE">[76]</span></a></sup> How cats are able to right themselves when falling has been investigated as the "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Falling_cat_problem" title="Falling cat problem" id="mwAgI">falling cat problem</a>".<sup about="#mwt486" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-77" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-77"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-77" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAgM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgQ">[77]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="12" id="mwAgU"><h3 id="Coats">Coats</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt489" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat coat genetics"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAgY"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt489" id="mwAgc">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_coat_genetics" title="Cat coat genetics">Cat coat genetics</a></div><p id="mwAgg">The cat family (Felidae) can pass down many colors and patterns to their offsprings. The domestic cat genes <i id="mwAgk">MC1R</i> and <i id="mwAgo">ASIP</i> allow for the variety of color in coats. The feline ASIP gene consists of three coding exons.<sup about="#mwt495" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-78" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-78"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-78" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwAgs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgw">[78]</span></a></sup> Three novel <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microsatellite" title="Microsatellite" id="mwAg0">microsatellite</a> markers linked to ASIP were isolated from a domestic cat BAC clone containing this gene and were used to perform <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Linkage_analysis" title="Linkage analysis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAg4">linkage analysis</a> in a pedigree of 89 domestic cats that segregated for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Melanism" title="Melanism" id="mwAg8">melanism</a>.<sup about="#mwt499" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-79" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-79"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-79" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 79;" id="mwAhA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhE">[79]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="13" id="mwAhI"><h2 id="Senses">Senses</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt500" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat senses"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAhM"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt500" id="mwAhQ">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_senses" title="Cat senses">Cat senses</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="14" id="mwAhU"><h3 id="Vision">Vision</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAhY"><a href="./File:TapetumLucidum.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAhc"><img resource="./File:TapetumLucidum.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/TapetumLucidum.JPG/220px-TapetumLucidum.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="2127" data-file-height="1518" data-file-type="bitmap" height="157" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/TapetumLucidum.JPG/330px-TapetumLucidum.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/TapetumLucidum.JPG/440px-TapetumLucidum.JPG 2x" id="mwAhg"/></a><figcaption id="mwAhk">Reflection of camera flash from the <i id="mwAho"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tapetum_lucidum" title="Tapetum lucidum" id="mwAhs">tapetum lucidum</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAhw"><a href="./File:Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAh0"><img alt="A tabby cat with a third, translucent eyelid covering part of either eye" resource="./File:Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg/220px-Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="4000" data-file-type="bitmap" height="293" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg/330px-Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg/440px-Tabby_cat_with_visible_nictitating_membrane.jpg 2x" id="mwAh4"/></a><figcaption id="mwAh8">A cat's nictitating membrane shown as it blinks</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAiA">Cats have excellent <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Night_vision" title="Night vision" id="mwAiE">night vision</a> and can see at only one-sixth the light level required for human vision.<sup about="#mwt510" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Case_64-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Case"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Case-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAiI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiM">[64]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt509" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"43"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAiQ"><span title="Page / location: 43"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>43<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> This is partly the result of cat eyes having a <i id="mwAiU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tapetum_lucidum" title="Tapetum lucidum" id="mwAiY">tapetum lucidum</a></i>, which reflects any light that passes through the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retina" title="Retina" id="mwAic">retina</a> back into the eye, thereby increasing the eye's sensitivity to dim light.<sup about="#mwt514" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-80" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-80"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-80" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 80;" id="mwAig"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAik">[80]</span></a></sup> Large pupils are an adaptation to dim light. The domestic cat has <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pupil#In_other_animals" title="Pupil" id="mwAio">slit pupils</a>, which allow it to focus bright light without <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chromatic_aberration" title="Chromatic aberration" id="mwAis">chromatic aberration</a>.<sup about="#mwt518" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-81" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-81"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;" id="mwAiw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAi0">[81]</span></a></sup> At low light, a cat's pupils expand to cover most of the exposed surface of its eyes.<sup about="#mwt522" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-82" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-82"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-82" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 82;" id="mwAi4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAi8">[82]</span></a></sup> The domestic cat has rather poor <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Color_vision" title="Color vision" id="mwAjA">color vision</a> and only two types of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cone_cell" title="Cone cell" id="mwAjE">cone cells</a>, optimized for sensitivity to blue and yellowish green; its ability to distinguish between red and green is limited.<sup about="#mwt526" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-83" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-83"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-83" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 83;" id="mwAjI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjM">[83]</span></a></sup> A response to middle wavelengths from a system other than the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rod_cell" title="Rod cell" id="mwAjQ">rod cells</a> might be due to a third type of cone. This appears to be an adaptation to low light levels rather than representing true <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trichromacy" title="Trichromacy" id="mwAjU">trichromatic</a> vision.<sup about="#mwt530" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-84" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-84"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-84" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;" id="mwAjY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjc">[84]</span></a></sup> Cats also have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nictitating_membrane" title="Nictitating membrane" id="mwAjg">nictitating membrane</a>, allowing them to blink without hindering their vision.</p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="15" id="mwAjk"><h3 id="Hearing">Hearing</h3>
<p id="mwAjo">The domestic cat's hearing is most acute in the range of 500<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAjs"> </span>Hz to 32<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAjw"> </span>kHz.<sup about="#mwt537" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-85" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-85"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-85" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;" id="mwAj0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAj4">[85]</span></a></sup> It can detect an extremely broad range of frequencies ranging from 55<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAj8"> </span>Hz to 79 kHz. It can hear a range of 10.5 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Octave" title="Octave" id="mwAkA">octaves</a>, while humans and dogs can hear ranges of about 9 octaves.<sup about="#mwt541" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-86" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-86"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-86" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 86;" id="mwAkE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkI">[86]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt545" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-87" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-87"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwAkM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkQ">[87]</span></a></sup>
Its hearing sensitivity is enhanced by its large movable outer ears, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pinna_(anatomy)" title="Pinna (anatomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAkU">pinnae</a>, which amplify sounds and help detect the location of a noise. It can detect <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ultrasound" title="Ultrasound" id="mwAkY">ultrasound</a>, which enables it to detect ultrasonic calls made by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mwAkc">rodent</a> prey.<sup about="#mwt552" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sunquist_88-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sunquist"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Sunquist-88"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Sunquist-88" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 88;" id="mwAkg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkk">[88]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt556" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-89" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-89"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-89" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 89;" id="mwAko"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAks">[89]</span></a></sup> Recent research has shown that cats have socio-spatial cognitive abilities to create mental maps of owners' locations based on hearing owners' voices.<sup about="#mwt560" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-90" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-90"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-90" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 90;" id="mwAkw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAk0">[90]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="16" id="mwAk4"><h3 id="Smell">Smell</h3>
<p id="mwAk8">Cats have an acute sense of smell, due in part to their well-developed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Olfactory_bulb" title="Olfactory bulb" id="mwAlA">olfactory bulb</a> and a large surface of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Olfactory_mucosa" title="Olfactory mucosa" id="mwAlE">olfactory mucosa</a>, about <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt567" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"5.8"},"2":{"wt":"cm2"},"3":{"wt":"sqin"},"frac":{"wt":"32"},"abbr":{"wt":"off"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAlI">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span about="#mwt567">5.8 square centimetres (</span><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt567"><span class="num">29</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">32</span></span><span about="#mwt567"> square inch)</span> in area, which is about twice that of humans<!-- impossible logic and only 1.7&#x2D;fold less than the average dog. -->.<sup about="#mwt573" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Moulton_1967_91-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Moulton 1967"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Moulton_1967-91"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Moulton_1967-91" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwAlM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlQ">[91]</span></a></sup> Cats and many other animals have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jacobson's_organ" title="Jacobson's organ" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAlU">Jacobson's organ</a> in their mouths that is used in the behavioral process of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flehmen_response" title="Flehmen response" id="mwAlY">flehmening</a>. It allows them to sense certain aromas in a way that humans cannot. Cats are sensitive to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_pheromone" title="Cat pheromone" id="mwAlc">pheromones</a> such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./3-mercapto-3-methylbutan-1-ol" title="3-mercapto-3-methylbutan-1-ol" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAlg">3-mercapto-3-methylbutan-1-ol</a>,<sup about="#mwt577" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-felinine_92-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"felinine"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-felinine-92"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-felinine-92" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;" id="mwAlk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlo">[92]</span></a></sup> which they use to communicate through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urine_spraying" title="Urine spraying" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAls">urine spraying</a> and marking with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scent_glands" title="Scent glands" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAlw">scent glands</a>.<sup about="#mwt578" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sommerville_93-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sommerville"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Sommerville-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 93;" id="mwAl0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAl4">[93]</span></a></sup> Many cats also respond strongly to plants that contain <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nepetalactone" title="Nepetalactone" id="mwAl8">nepetalactone</a>, especially <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Catnip" title="Catnip" id="mwAmA">catnip</a>, as they can detect that substance at less than one part per billion.<sup about="#mwt582" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-94" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-94"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-94" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 94;" id="mwAmE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmI">[94]</span></a></sup> About 70–80% of cats are affected by nepetalactone.<sup about="#mwt586" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-95" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-95"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-95" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 95;" id="mwAmM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmQ">[95]</span></a></sup> This response is also produced by other plants, such as silver vine (<i id="mwAmU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Actinidia_polygama" title="Actinidia polygama" id="mwAmY">Actinidia polygama</a></i>) and the herb <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Valerian_(herb)" title="Valerian (herb)" id="mwAmc">valerian</a>; it may be caused by the smell of these plants mimicking a pheromone and stimulating cats' social or sexual behaviors.<sup about="#mwt590" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Tucker_96-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Tucker"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Tucker-96"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Tucker-96" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 96;" id="mwAmg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmk">[96]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="17" id="mwAmo"><h3 id="Taste">Taste</h3>
<p id="mwAms">Cats have relatively few <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taste_bud" title="Taste bud" id="mwAmw">taste buds</a> compared to humans (470 or so versus more than 9,000 on the human tongue).<sup about="#mwt599" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sch_97-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sch"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sch-97"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-sch-97" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 97;" id="mwAm0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAm4">[97]</span></a></sup> Domestic and wild cats share a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taste_receptor#Loss_of_function" title="Taste receptor" id="mwAm8">taste receptor gene mutation</a> that keeps their sweet taste buds from binding to sugary molecules, leaving them with no ability to taste <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sweetness" title="Sweetness" id="mwAnA">sweetness</a>.<sup about="#mwt604" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-98" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-98"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwAnE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnI">[98]</span></a></sup> Their taste buds instead respond to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acid" title="Acid" id="mwAnM">acids</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amino_acid" title="Amino acid" id="mwAnQ">amino acids</a> like protein, and bitter tastes.<sup about="#mwt608" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bradshaw2006_99-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bradshaw2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bradshaw2006-99"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bradshaw2006-99" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 99;" id="mwAnU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnY">[99]</span></a></sup> Cats also have a distinct temperature preference for their food, preferring food with a temperature around <span about="#mwt595" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"38"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAnc">38</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt595"> </span><span about="#mwt595">°C (100</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt595"> </span><span about="#mwt595">°F)</span> which is similar to that of a fresh kill and routinely rejecting food presented cold or refrigerated (which would signal to the cat that the "prey" item is long dead and therefore possibly toxic or decomposing).<sup about="#mwt609" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sch_97-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sch"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-sch-97" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 97;" id="mwAng"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnk">[97]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="18" id="mwAno"><h3 id="Whiskers">Whiskers</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAns"><a href="./File:Kittyply_edit1.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAnw"><img resource="./File:Kittyply_edit1.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kittyply_edit1.jpg/220px-Kittyply_edit1.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1728" data-file-height="1152" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kittyply_edit1.jpg/330px-Kittyply_edit1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kittyply_edit1.jpg/440px-Kittyply_edit1.jpg 2x" id="mwAn0"/></a><figcaption id="mwAn4">The whiskers of a cat are highly sensitive to touch.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAn8">To aid with navigation and sensation, cats have dozens of movable <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vibrissa" title="Vibrissa" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAoA">whiskers (vibrissae)</a> over their body, especially their faces. These provide information on the width of gaps and on the location of objects in the dark, both by touching objects directly and by sensing air currents; they also trigger protective <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blink_reflex" title="Blink reflex" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAoE">blink reflexes</a> to protect the eyes from damage.<sup about="#mwt612" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Case_64-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Case"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Case-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAoI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoM">[64]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt611" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"47"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAoQ"><span title="Page / location: 47"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>47<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="19" id="mwAoU"><h2 id="Behavior">Behavior</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt613" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat behavior"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAoY"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt613" id="mwAoc">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_behavior" title="Cat behavior">Cat behavior</a></div>
<p id="mwAog">Outdoor cats are active both day and night, although they tend to be slightly more active at night.<sup about="#mwt623" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-100" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-100"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-100" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 100;" id="mwAok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoo">[100]</span></a></sup> Domestic cats spend the majority of their time in the vicinity of their homes but can range many hundreds of meters from this central point. They establish <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)" id="mwAos">territories</a> that vary considerably in size, in one study ranging from <span about="#mwt619" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"7"},"2":{"wt":"to(-)"},"3":{"wt":"28"},"4":{"wt":"ha"},"5":{"wt":"acre"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAow">7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt619"> </span><span about="#mwt619">to 28 hectares (17–69 acres)</span>.<sup about="#mwt627" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-101" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-101"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwAo0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAo4">[101]</span></a></sup> The timing of cats' activity is quite flexible and varied, which means house cats may be more <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crepuscular" title="Crepuscular" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAo8">active in the morning and evening</a>, as a response to greater human activity at these times.<sup about="#mwt631" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-102" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-102"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-102" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 102;" id="mwApA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApE">[102]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwApI">Cats conserve energy by sleeping more than most animals, especially as they grow older. The daily duration of sleep varies, usually between 12 and 16 hours, with 13 and 14 being the average. Some cats can sleep as much as 20 hours. The term "cat nap" for a short rest refers to the cat's tendency to fall asleep (lightly) for a brief period. While asleep, cats experience short periods of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rapid_eye_movement_sleep" title="Rapid eye movement sleep" id="mwApM">rapid eye movement sleep</a> often accompanied by muscle twitches, which suggests they are dreaming.<sup about="#mwt636" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-103" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-103"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-103" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 103;" id="mwApQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApU">[103]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="20" id="mwApY"><h3 id="Sociability">Sociability</h3>
<p id="mwApc">The social behavior of the domestic cat ranges from widely dispersed individuals to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feral_cat_colony" title="Feral cat colony" class="mw-redirect" id="mwApg">feral cat colonies</a> that gather around a food source, based on groups of co-operating females.<sup about="#mwt644" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Crowell-davis2004_104-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Crowell-davis2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Crowell-davis2004-104"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Crowell-davis2004-104" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;" id="mwApk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApo">[104]</span></a></sup> Within such groups, one cat is usually dominant over the others.<sup about="#mwt648" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-105" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-105"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-105" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwAps"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApw">[105]</span></a></sup> Each cat in a colony holds a distinct territory, with sexually active males having the largest territories, which are about 10 times larger than those of female cats and may overlap with several females' territories. These territories are marked by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urine_spraying" title="Urine spraying" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAp0">urine spraying</a>, by rubbing objects at head height with secretions from facial glands, and by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Defecation" title="Defecation" id="mwAp4">defecation</a>.<sup about="#mwt652" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sommerville_93-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sommerville"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Sommerville-93"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Sommerville-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 93;" id="mwAp8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqA">[93]</span></a></sup> Between these territories are neutral areas where cats watch and greet one another without territorial conflicts. Outside these neutral areas, territory holders usually chase away stranger cats, at first by staring, hissing, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Growling" title="Growling" id="mwAqE">growling</a> and, if that does not work, by short but noisy and violent attacks. Despite this colonial organization, cats do not have a social survival strategy or a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herd_behavior" title="Herd behavior" id="mwAqI">pack mentality</a>, and always hunt alone.<sup about="#mwt653" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bradshaw_106-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bradshaw"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bradshaw-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwAqM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqQ">[106]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAqU">Life in proximity to humans and other domestic animals has led to a symbiotic social adaptation in cats, and cats may express great affection toward humans or other animals. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ethology" title="Ethology" id="mwAqY">Ethologically</a>, a cat's human keeper functions as if a mother surrogate.<sup about="#mwt660" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-107" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-107"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-107" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;" id="mwAqc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqg">[107]</span></a></sup> Adult cats live their lives in a kind of extended kittenhood, a form of behavioral <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neoteny" title="Neoteny" id="mwAqk">neoteny</a>. Their high-pitched sounds may mimic the cries of a hungry human infant, making them particularly difficult for humans to ignore.<sup about="#mwt664" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-McComb_2009_108-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"McComb 2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-McComb_2009-108"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-McComb_2009-108" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 108;" id="mwAqo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqs">[108]</span></a></sup> Some pet cats are poorly socialized. In particular, older cats show aggressiveness toward newly arrived kittens, which include biting and scratching; this type of behavior is known as feline asocial aggression.<sup about="#mwt668" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Levine_2005_109-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Levine 2005"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Levine_2005-109"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Levine_2005-109" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwAqw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAq0">[109]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAq4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Redirected_aggression" title="Redirected aggression" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAq8">Redirected aggression</a> is a common form of aggression which can occur in multiple cat households. In redirected aggression there is usually something that agitates the cat: this could be a sight, sound, or another source of stimuli which causes a heightened level of anxiety or arousal. If the cat cannot attack the stimuli, it may direct anger elsewhere by attacking or directing aggression to the nearest cat, dog, human or other being.<sup about="#mwt674" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Horwitz_110-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Horwitz"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Horwitz-110"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Horwitz-110" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 110;" id="mwArA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArE">[110]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt678" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Behaviorist_111-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Behaviorist"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Behaviorist-111"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Behaviorist-111" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 111;" id="mwArI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArM">[111]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwArQ">Domestic cats' <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scent_rubbing" title="Scent rubbing" id="mwArU">scent rubbing</a> behavior toward humans or other cats is thought to be a feline means for social bonding.<sup about="#mwt683" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-112" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-112"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-112" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 112;" id="mwArY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArc">[112]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="21" id="mwArg"><h3 id="Communication">Communication</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt684" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat communication"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwArk"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt684" id="mwAro">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_communication" title="Cat communication">Cat communication</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwArs"><a href="./File:Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwArw"><img resource="./File:Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg/220px-Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2250" data-file-height="1500" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg/330px-Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg/440px-Domestic_Cat_Face_Shot.jpg 2x" id="mwAr0"/></a><figcaption id="mwAr4">Vocalizing domestic cat</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAr8">Domestic cats use many <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_communication" title="Animal communication" id="mwAsA">vocalizations</a> for communication, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purr" title="Purr" id="mwAsE">purring</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trill_consonant" title="Trill consonant" id="mwAsI">trilling</a>, hissing, growling/snarling, grunting, and several different forms of meowing.<sup about="#mwt692" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Moelk1944_7-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Moelk1944"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Moelk1944-7" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwAsM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsQ">[7]</span></a></sup> Their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_body_language" title="Cat body language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAsU">body language</a>, including position of ears and tail, relaxation of the whole body, and kneading of the paws, are all indicators of mood. The tail and ears are particularly important social signal mechanisms in cats. A raised tail indicates a friendly greeting, and flattened ears indicates hostility. Tail-raising also indicates the cat's position in the group's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Social_hierarchy" title="Social hierarchy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAsY">social hierarchy</a>, with dominant individuals raising their tails less often than subordinate ones.<sup about="#mwt696" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-113" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-113"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-113" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 113;" id="mwAsc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsg">[113]</span></a></sup> Feral cats are generally silent.<sup about="#mwt700" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Jensen_114-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Jensen"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Jensen-114"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Jensen-114" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 114;" id="mwAsk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAso">[114]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt691" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"208"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAss"><span title="Page / location: 208"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>208<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Nose-to-nose touching is also a common greeting and may be followed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Social_grooming" title="Social grooming" id="mwAsw">social grooming</a>, which is solicited by one of the cats raising and tilting its head.<sup about="#mwt701" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Crowell-davis2004_104-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Crowell-davis2004"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Crowell-davis2004-104" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;" id="mwAs0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAs4">[104]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAs8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purring" title="Purring" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAtA">Purring</a> may have developed as an evolutionary advantage as a signaling mechanism of reassurance between mother cats and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Breastfeeding" title="Breastfeeding" id="mwAtE">nursing</a> kittens, who are thought to use it as a care-soliciting signal.<sup about="#mwt703" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bradshaw2012_115-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bradshaw2012"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-bradshaw2012-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwAtI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtM">[115]</span></a></sup>
Post-nursing cats also often purr as a sign of contentment: when being petted, becoming relaxed,<sup about="#mwt710" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-BruelKjaer_116-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"BruelKjaer"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-BruelKjaer-116"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-BruelKjaer-116" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 116;" id="mwAtQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtU">[116]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt714" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-IsnareCom_117-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"IsnareCom"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-IsnareCom-117"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-IsnareCom-117" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 117;" id="mwAtY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtc">[117]</span></a></sup> or eating. Even though purring is popularly interpreted as indicative of pleasure, it has been recorded in a wide variety of circumstances, most of which involve physical contact between the cat and another, presumably trusted individual.<sup about="#mwt715" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bradshaw2012_115-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bradshaw2012"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-bradshaw2012-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwAtg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtk">[115]</span></a></sup> Some cats have been observed to purr continuously when
chronically ill or in apparent pain.<sup about="#mwt720" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-118" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-118"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-118" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwAto"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAts">[118]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAtw">The exact mechanism by which cats purr has long been elusive, but it has been proposed that purring is generated via a series of sudden build-ups and releases of pressure as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Glottis" title="Glottis" id="mwAt0">glottis</a> is opened and closed, which causes the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vocal_folds" title="Vocal folds" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAt4">vocal folds</a> to separate forcefully. The laryngeal muscles in control of the glottis
are thought to be driven by a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neural_oscillator?action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Neural oscillator" class="new" typeof="mw:LocalizedAttrs" data-mw-i18n='{"title":{"lang":"x-page","key":"red-link-title","params":["Neural oscillator"]}}' id="mwAt8">neural oscillator</a> which generates a cycle of contraction and release every 30-40
milliseconds (giving a frequency of 33 to 25 Hz).<sup about="#mwt727" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bradshaw2012_115-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bradshaw2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bradshaw2012-115"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-bradshaw2012-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwAuA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuE">[115]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt731" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-119" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-119"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwAuI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuM">[119]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt735" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-120" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-120"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 120;" id="mwAuQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuU">[120]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="22" id="mwAuY"><h3 id="Grooming">Grooming</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAuc"><a href="./File:Cat_tongue_macro.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAug"><img resource="./File:Cat_tongue_macro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Cat_tongue_macro.jpg/220px-Cat_tongue_macro.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="528" data-file-type="bitmap" height="145" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Cat_tongue_macro.jpg/330px-Cat_tongue_macro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Cat_tongue_macro.jpg/440px-Cat_tongue_macro.jpg 2x" id="mwAuk"/></a><figcaption id="mwAuo">The hooked <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lingual_papilla" title="Lingual papilla" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAus">papillae</a> on a cat's tongue act like a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hairbrush" title="Hairbrush" id="mwAuw">hairbrush</a> to help clean and detangle fur</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAu0">Cats are known for spending considerable amounts of time licking their coats to keep them clean.<sup about="#mwt742" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hairballs_121-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hairballs"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-hairballs-121" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 121;" id="mwAu4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAu8">[121]</span></a></sup> The cat's tongue has backward-facing spines about 500 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Micrometre" title="Micrometre" id="mwAvA">μm</a> long, which are called <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lingual_papilla" title="Lingual papilla" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAvE">papillae</a>. These contain <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Keratin" title="Keratin" id="mwAvI">keratin</a> which makes them rigid<sup about="#mwt746" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Boshel_1982_122-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Boshel 1982"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Boshel_1982-122"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Boshel_1982-122" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 122;" id="mwAvM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvQ">[122]</span></a></sup> so the papillae act like a hairbrush. Some cats, particularly longhaired cats, occasionally regurgitate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hairball" title="Hairball" id="mwAvU">hairballs</a> of fur that have collected in their stomachs from grooming. These clumps of fur are usually sausage-shaped and about <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" about="#mwt739" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2"},"2":{"wt":"–"},"3":{"wt":"3"},"4":{"wt":"cm"},"frac":{"wt":"4"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAvY"/><span about="#mwt739">2–3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt739"> </span><span about="#mwt739">cm (</span><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt739"><span class="num">3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">4</span></span><span about="#mwt739">–</span><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt739">1<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">4</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt739"> </span><span about="#mwt739">in)</span> long. Hairballs can be prevented with remedies that ease elimination of the hair through the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gut_(anatomy)" title="Gut (anatomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAvc">gut</a>, as well as regular grooming of the coat with a comb or stiff brush.<sup about="#mwt750" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hairballs_121-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hairballs"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-hairballs-121"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-hairballs-121" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 121;" id="mwAvg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvk">[121]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="23" id="mwAvo"><h3 id="Fighting">Fighting</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAvs"><a href="./File:GAto.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAvw"><img resource="./File:GAto.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg/220px-Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="935" data-file-type="bitmap" height="171" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg/330px-Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg/440px-Gato_enervado_pola_presencia_dun_can.jpg 2x" id="mwAv0"/></a><figcaption id="mwAv4">A domestic cat's arched back, raised fur, and open-mouthed hiss are signs of aggression.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAv8">Among domestic cats, males are more likely to fight than females.<sup about="#mwt758" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lindell_123-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lindell"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lindell-123"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Lindell-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwAwA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwE">[123]</span></a></sup> Among feral cats, the most common reason for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Catfight_(animal_behavior)" title="Catfight (animal behavior)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAwI">cat fighting</a> is competition between two males to mate with a female. In such cases, most fights are won by the heavier male.<sup about="#mwt762" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-courtship_124-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"courtship"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-courtship-124"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-courtship-124" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 124;" id="mwAwM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwQ">[124]</span></a></sup> Another common reason for fighting in domestic cats is the difficulty of establishing territories within a small home.<sup about="#mwt763" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lindell_123-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lindell"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Lindell-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwAwU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwY">[123]</span></a></sup> Female cats also fight over territory or to defend their kittens. Neutering will decrease or eliminate this behavior in many cases, suggesting that the behavior is linked to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sex_hormone" title="Sex hormone" id="mwAwc">sex hormones</a>.<sup about="#mwt767" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-125" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-125"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-125" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 125;" id="mwAwg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwk">[125]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAwo">When cats become aggressive, they try to make themselves appear larger and more threatening by raising their fur, arching their backs, turning sideways and hissing or spitting.<sup about="#mwt773" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-behaviourguide_126-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"behaviourguide"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-behaviourguide-126"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-behaviourguide-126" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 126;" id="mwAws"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAww">[126]</span></a></sup> Often, the ears are pointed down and back to avoid damage to the inner ear and potentially listen for any changes behind them while focused forward. Cats may also vocalize loudly and bare their teeth in an effort to further intimidate their opponents. Fights usually consist of grappling and delivering powerful slaps to the face and body with the forepaws as well as bites. Cats also throw themselves to the ground in a defensive posture to rake their opponent's belly with their powerful hind legs.<sup about="#mwt777" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-127" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-127"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-127" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 127;" id="mwAw0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAw4">[127]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAw8">Serious damage is rare, as the fights are usually short in duration, with the loser running away with little more than a few scratches to the face and ears. Fights for mating rights are typically more severe and injuries may include deep puncture wounds and lacerations. Normally, serious injuries from fighting are limited to infections of scratches and bites, though these can occasionally kill cats if untreated. In addition, bites are probably the main route of transmission of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feline_immunodeficiency_virus" title="Feline immunodeficiency virus" id="mwAxA">feline immunodeficiency virus</a>.<sup about="#mwt784" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Pederson_1989_128-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Pederson 1989"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Pederson_1989-128"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Pederson_1989-128" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 128;" id="mwAxE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxI">[128]</span></a></sup> Sexually active males are usually involved in many fights during their lives, and often have decidedly battered faces with obvious scars and cuts to their ears and nose.<sup about="#mwt788" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-129" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-129"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-129" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 129;" id="mwAxM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxQ">[129]</span></a></sup> Cats are willing to threaten animals larger than them to defend their territory, such as dogs and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_fox" title="Red fox" id="mwAxU">foxes</a>.<sup about="#mwt792" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-130" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-130"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-130" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 130;" id="mwAxY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxc">[130]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="24" id="mwAxg"><h3 id="Hunting_and_feeding">Hunting and feeding</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt793" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat food"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAxk"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt793" id="mwAxo">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_food" title="Cat food">Cat food</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAxs"><a href="./File:Kot_z_myszą.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAxw"><img resource="./File:Kot_z_myszą.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg/220px-Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2171" data-file-height="2169" data-file-type="bitmap" height="220" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg/330px-Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg/440px-Kot_z_mysz%C4%85.jpg 2x" id="mwAx0"/></a><figcaption id="mwAx4">A domestic cat with its prey, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deermouse" title="Deermouse" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAx8">deermouse</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAyA">The shape and structure of cats' cheeks is insufficient to allow them to take in liquids using suction. Therefore, when drinking they lap with the tongue to draw liquid upward into their mouths. Lapping at a rate of four times a second, the cat touches the smooth tip of its tongue to the surface of the water, and quickly retracts it like a corkscrew, drawing water upward.<sup about="#mwt801" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Reis_2010_131-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Reis 2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Reis_2010-131"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Reis_2010-131" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 131;" id="mwAyE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyI">[131]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt805" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kim_2012_132-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kim 2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kim_2012-132"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kim_2012-132" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwAyM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyQ">[132]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAyU">Feral cats and free-fed house cats consume several small meals in a day. The frequency and size of meals varies between individuals. They select food based on its temperature, smell and texture; they dislike chilled foods and respond most strongly to moist foods rich in amino acids, which are similar to meat. Cats reject novel flavors (a response termed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neophobia" title="Neophobia" id="mwAyY">neophobia</a>) and learn quickly to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taste_aversion" title="Taste aversion" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAyc">avoid foods that have tasted unpleasant</a> in the past.<sup about="#mwt813" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bradshaw_106-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bradshaw"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bradshaw-106"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bradshaw-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwAyg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyk">[106]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt817" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Zaghini_133-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Zaghini"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Zaghini-133"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Zaghini-133" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 133;" id="mwAyo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAys">[133]</span></a></sup> It is also a common misconception that cats like milk/cream, as they tend to avoid sweet food and milk. Most adult cats are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lactose_intolerant" title="Lactose intolerant" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAyw">lactose intolerant</a>; the sugar in milk is not easily digested and may cause soft stools or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea" id="mwAy0">diarrhea</a>.<sup about="#mwt821" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kienzle_1994_134-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kienzle 1994"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kienzle_1994-134"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kienzle_1994-134" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 134;" id="mwAy4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAy8">[134]</span></a></sup> Some also develop odd eating habits and like to eat or chew on things like wool, plastic, cables, paper, string, aluminum foil, or even coal. This condition, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pica_(disorder)" title="Pica (disorder)" id="mwAzA">pica</a>, can threaten their health, depending on the amount and toxicity of the items eaten.<sup about="#mwt825" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bradshaw_1997_135-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bradshaw 1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bradshaw_1997-135"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Bradshaw_1997-135" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 135;" id="mwAzE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzI">[135]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAzM">Cats hunt small prey, primarily birds and rodents,<sup about="#mwt836" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Woods_136-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Woods"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Woods-136"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Woods-136" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 136;" id="mwAzQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzU">[136]</span></a></sup> and are often used as a form of pest control.<sup about="#mwt840" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-137" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-137"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-137" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 137;" id="mwAzY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzc">[137]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt844" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-138" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-138"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-138" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwAzg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzk">[138]</span></a></sup> Cats use two hunting strategies, either stalking prey actively, or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ambush_predator" title="Ambush predator" id="mwAzo">waiting in ambush</a> until an animal comes close enough to be captured.<sup about="#mwt848" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-How_Cats_Evolved_to_Win_the_Internet_139-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"How Cats Evolved to Win the Internet"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-How_Cats_Evolved_to_Win_the_Internet-139"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-How_Cats_Evolved_to_Win_the_Internet-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwAzs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzw">[139]</span></a></sup> The strategy used depends on the prey species in the area, with cats waiting in ambush outside burrows, but tending to actively stalk birds.<sup about="#mwt852" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Turner_2000_140-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Turner 2000"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Turner_2000-140"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Turner_2000-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 140;" id="mwAz0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAz4">[140]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt832" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"153"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAz8"><span title="Page / location: 153"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>153<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Domestic cats are a major <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_predation_on_wildlife" title="Cat predation on wildlife" id="mwA0A">predator of wildlife</a> in the United States, killing an estimated 1.3 to 4.0<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwA0E"> </span>billion birds and 6.3 to 22.3<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwA0I"> </span>billion mammals annually.<sup about="#mwt856" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NC012913_141-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NC012913"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NC012913-141"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-NC012913-141" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 141;" id="mwA0M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0Q">[141]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA0U">Certain species appear more susceptible than others; in one English village, for example, 30% of house sparrow mortality was linked to the domestic cat.<sup about="#mwt863" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Chucher_1987_142-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Chucher 1987"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Chucher_1987-142"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Chucher_1987-142" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 142;" id="mwA0Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0c">[142]</span></a></sup> In the recovery of ringed robins (<i id="mwA0g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erithacus_rubecula" title="Erithacus rubecula" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA0k">Erithacus rubecula</a></i>) and dunnocks (<i id="mwA0o"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Prunella_modularis" title="Prunella modularis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA0s">Prunella modularis</a></i>) in Britain, 31% of deaths were a result of cat predation.<sup about="#mwt867" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mead_1982_183–186_143-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mead 1982 183–186"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Mead_1982_183–186-143"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Mead_1982_183–186-143" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 143;" id="mwA0w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA00">[143]</span></a></sup> In parts of North America, the presence of larger carnivores such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coyote" title="Coyote" id="mwA04">coyotes</a> which prey on cats and other small predators reduces the effect of predation by cats and other small predators such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Opossum" title="Opossum" id="mwA08">opossums</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Raccoon" title="Raccoon" id="mwA1A">raccoons</a> on bird numbers and variety.<sup about="#mwt871" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Crooks_1999_144-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Crooks 1999"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Crooks_1999-144"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Crooks_1999-144" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 144;" id="mwA1E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1I">[144]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA1M">Perhaps the best-known element of cats' hunting behavior, which is commonly misunderstood and often appalls cat owners because it looks like torture, is that cats often appear to "play" with prey by releasing and recapturing it. This <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_and_mouse" title="Cat and mouse" id="mwA1Q">cat and mouse</a> behavior is due to an instinctive imperative to ensure that the prey is weak enough to be killed without endangering the cat.<sup about="#mwt876" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-145" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-145"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-145" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 145;" id="mwA1U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1Y">[145]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA1c">Another poorly understood element of cat hunting behavior is the presentation of prey to human guardians. One explanation is that cats adopt humans into their social group and share excess kill with others in the group according to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dominance_hierarchy" title="Dominance hierarchy" id="mwA1g">dominance hierarchy</a>, in which humans are reacted to as if they are at or near the top.<sup about="#mwt884" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Leyhausen_1978_146-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Leyhausen 1978"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Leyhausen_1978-146"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Leyhausen_1978-146" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 146;" id="mwA1k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1o">[146]</span></a></sup> Another explanation is that they attempt to teach their guardians to hunt or to help their human as if feeding "an elderly cat, or an inept kitten".<sup about="#mwt888" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Morris_Catwatching_1_147-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Morris Catwatching 1"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Morris_Catwatching_1-147"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Morris_Catwatching_1-147" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 147;" id="mwA1s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1w">[147]</span></a></sup> This hypothesis is inconsistent with the fact that male cats also bring home prey, despite males having negligible involvement in raising kittens.<sup about="#mwt889" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Turner_2000_140-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Turner 2000"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Turner_2000-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 140;" id="mwA10"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA14">[140]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt880" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"153"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA18"><span title="Page / location: 153"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>153<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="25" id="mwA2A"><h3 id="Play">Play</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt890" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat play and toys"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA2E"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt890" id="mwA2I">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_play_and_toys" title="Cat play and toys">Cat play and toys</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" data-mw='{"attribs":[["thumbtime",{"txt":"4"}],["alt",{"txt":"Play fight between kittens, age 14 weeks"}]]}' id="mwA2M"><span id="mwA2Q"><video poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm/220px-seek%3D4-Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" height="124" width="220" resource="./File:Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm" id="mwA2U"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="426" data-height="240" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" id="mwA2o"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/45/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm.240p.webm" type='video/webm;
