codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="640" data-height="360" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" id="mwA20"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/45/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" id="mwA24"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/45/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm/Play_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm.480p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" id="mwA28"/><track kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3APlay_fight_between_cats.webmhd.webm&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="en" label="English ‪(en)‬" data-mwtitle="" data-dir="ltr" id="mwA3A"/></video></span><figcaption id="mwA3E">Play fight between kittens aged 14 weeks</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwA3I">Domestic cats, especially young kittens, are known for their love of play. This behavior mimics hunting and is important in helping kittens learn to stalk, capture, and kill prey.<sup about="#mwt898" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-148" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-148"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-148" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 148;" id="mwA3M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3Q">[148]</span></a></sup> Cats also engage in play fighting, with each other and with humans. This behavior may be a way for cats to practice the skills needed for real combat, and might also reduce any fear they associate with launching attacks on other animals.<sup about="#mwt902" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-149" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-149"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwA3U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3Y">[149]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA3c">Cats also tend to play with toys more when they are hungry.<sup about="#mwt910" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-150" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-150"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-150" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 150;" id="mwA3g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3k">[150]</span></a></sup> Owing to the close similarity between play and hunting, cats prefer to play with objects that resemble prey, such as small furry toys that move rapidly, but rapidly lose interest. They become <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Habituation" title="Habituation" id="mwA3o">habituated</a> to a toy they have played with before.<sup about="#mwt914" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-151" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-151"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-151" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 151;" id="mwA3s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3w">[151]</span></a></sup> String is often used as a toy, but if it is eaten, it can become caught at the base of the cat's tongue and then move into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intestine" title="Intestine" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA30">intestines</a>, a medical emergency which can cause serious illness, even death.<sup about="#mwt918" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-152" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-152"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-152" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 152;" id="mwA34"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA38">[152]</span></a></sup> Owing to the risks posed by cats eating string, it is sometimes replaced with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Laser_pointer" title="Laser pointer" id="mwA4A">laser pointer</a>'s dot, which cats may chase.<sup about="#mwt923" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-153" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-153"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-153" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 153;" id="mwA4E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA4I">[153]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="26" id="mwA4M"><h3 id="Reproduction">Reproduction</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA4Q"><a href="./File:Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA4U"><img resource="./File:Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg/220px-Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3340" data-file-height="2504" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg/330px-Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg/440px-Cats_having_sex_in_Israel.jpg 2x" id="mwA4Y"/></a><figcaption id="mwA4c">When cats mate, the tomcat (male) bites the scruff of the female's neck as she assumes a position conducive to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mating" title="Mating" id="mwA4g">mating</a> known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lordosis_behavior" title="Lordosis behavior" id="mwA4k">lordosis behavior</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt924" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Kitten"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA4o"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt924" id="mwA4s">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kitten" title="Kitten">Kitten</a></div>

<p id="mwA4w">Female cats, called queens, are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polyestrous" title="Polyestrous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA40">polyestrous</a> with several <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Estrus" title="Estrus" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA44">estrus</a> cycles during a year, lasting usually 21 days. They are usually ready to mate between early February and August.<sup about="#mwt931" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Jemmett1977_154-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Jemmett1977"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Jemmett1977-154"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Jemmett1977-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwA48"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5A">[154]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA5E">Several males, called tomcats, are attracted to a female in heat. They fight over her, and the victor wins the right to mate. At first, the female rejects the male, but eventually, the female allows the male to mate. The female utters a loud yowl as the male pulls out of her because a male cat's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penis" title="Penis" id="mwA5I">penis</a> has a band of about 120–150 backward-pointing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penile_spines" title="Penile spines" id="mwA5M">penile spines</a>, which are about <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" about="#mwt933" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1"},"2":{"wt":"mm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"frac":{"wt":"32"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5Q"/><span about="#mwt933">1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt933"> </span><span about="#mwt933">mm (</span><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt933"><span class="num">1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">32</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt933"> </span><span about="#mwt933">in)</span> long; upon withdrawal of the penis, the spines may provide the female with increased sexual stimulation, which acts to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Induced_ovulation_(animals)" title="Induced ovulation (animals)" id="mwA5U">induce ovulation</a>.<sup about="#mwt939" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Aronson_1967_155-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Aronson 1967"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Aronson_1967-155"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Aronson_1967-155" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 155;" id="mwA5Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5c">[155]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA5g">After mating, the female cleans her <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vulva" title="Vulva" id="mwA5k">vulva</a> thoroughly. If a male attempts to mate with her at this point, the female attacks him. After about 20 to 30 minutes, once the female is finished grooming, the cycle will repeat.<sup about="#mwt943" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-compendium_156-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"compendium"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-compendium-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwA5o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5s">[156]</span></a></sup> Because ovulation is not always triggered by a single mating, females may not be impregnated by the first male with which they mate.<sup about="#mwt947" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Wildt_1980_157-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Wildt 1980"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Wildt_1980-157"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Wildt_1980-157" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 157;" id="mwA5w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA50">[157]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, cats are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Superfecundation" title="Superfecundation" id="mwA54">superfecund</a>; that is, a female may mate with more than one male when she is in heat, with the result that different kittens in a litter may have different fathers.<sup about="#mwt951" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-compendium_156-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"compendium"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-compendium-156"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-compendium-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwA58"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6A">[156]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA6E">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Morula" title="Morula" id="mwA6I">morula</a> forms 124 hours after conception. At 148 hours, early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blastocyst" title="Blastocyst" id="mwA6M">blastocysts</a> form. At 10–12 days, implantation occurs.<sup about="#mwt958" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-158" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-158"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-158" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 158;" id="mwA6Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6U">[158]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gestation" title="Gestation" id="mwA6Y">gestation</a> of queens lasts between 64 and 67 days, with an average of 65 days.<sup about="#mwt959" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Jemmett1977_154-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Jemmett1977"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Jemmett1977-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwA6c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6g">[154]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt963" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Tsutsui_1993_159-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Tsutsui 1993"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Tsutsui_1993-159"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Tsutsui_1993-159" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 159;" id="mwA6k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6o">[159]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA6s"><a href="./File:Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA6w"><img resource="./File:Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg/170px-Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1554" data-file-height="2321" data-file-type="bitmap" height="254" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg/255px-Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg/340px-Radiography_of_a_pregnant_cat.jpg 2x" id="mwA60"/></a><figcaption id="mwA64">Radiography of a pregnant cat. The skeletons of two fetuses are visible on the left and right of the uterus.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA68"><a href="./File:1dayoldkitten.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA7A"><img resource="./File:1dayoldkitten.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/1dayoldkitten.JPG/220px-1dayoldkitten.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="801" data-file-height="555" data-file-type="bitmap" height="152" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/1dayoldkitten.JPG/330px-1dayoldkitten.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/1dayoldkitten.JPG/440px-1dayoldkitten.JPG 2x" id="mwA7E"/></a><figcaption id="mwA7I">A newborn kitten</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwA7M">Data on the reproductive capacity of more than 2,300 free-ranging queens were collected during a study between May 1998 and October 2000. They had one to six kittens per <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Litter_(animal)" title="Litter (animal)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA7Q">litter</a>, with an average of three kittens. They produced a mean of 1.4 litters per year, but a maximum of three litters in a year. Of 169 kittens, 127 died before they were six months old due to a trauma caused in most cases by dog attacks and road accidents.<sup about="#mwt965" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nutter2004_9-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nutter2004"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Nutter2004-9" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" id="mwA7U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA7Y">[9]</span></a></sup>
The first litter is usually smaller than subsequent litters. Kittens are weaned between six and seven weeks of age. Queens normally reach sexual maturity at 5–10 months, and males at 5–7 months. This varies depending on breed.<sup about="#mwt968" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-compendium_156-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"compendium"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-compendium-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwA7c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA7g">[156]</span></a></sup> Kittens reach <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Puberty" title="Puberty" id="mwA7k">puberty</a> at the age of 9–10 months.<sup about="#mwt969" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Jemmett1977_154-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Jemmett1977"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Jemmett1977-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwA7o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA7s">[154]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA7w">Cats are ready to go to new homes at about 12 weeks of age, when they are ready to leave their mother.<sup about="#mwt977" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-160" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-160"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-160" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 160;" id="mwA70"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA74">[160]</span></a></sup> They can be surgically <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neutering" title="Neutering" id="mwA78">sterilized</a> (spayed or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Castration" title="Castration" id="mwA8A">castrated</a>) as early as seven weeks to limit unwanted reproduction.<sup about="#mwt981" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-161" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-161"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-161" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 161;" id="mwA8E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8I">[161]</span></a></sup> This surgery also prevents undesirable sex-related behavior, such as aggression, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spraying_(animal_behavior)" title="Spraying (animal behavior)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8M">territory marking</a> (spraying urine) in males and yowling (calling) in females. Traditionally, this surgery was performed at around six to nine months of age, but it is increasingly being performed before <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Puberty" title="Puberty" id="mwA8Q">puberty</a>, at about three to six months.<sup about="#mwt985" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-162" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-162"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-162" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 162;" id="mwA8U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8Y">[162]</span></a></sup> In the United States, about 80% of household cats are neutered.<sup about="#mwt989" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-163" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-163"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-163" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 163;" id="mwA8c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8g">[163]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="27" id="mwA8k"><h2 id="Lifespan_and_health">Lifespan and health</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt990" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat health"},"2":{"wt":"Aging in cats"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA8o"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt990" id="mwA8s">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_health" title="Cat health">Cat health</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aging_in_cats" title="Aging in cats">Aging in cats</a></div>
<p id="mwA8w">The average lifespan of pet cats has risen in recent decades. In the early 1980s, it was about seven years,<sup about="#mwt1004" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kraft1998_164-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kraft1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kraft1998-164"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kraft1998-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwA80"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA84">[164]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt998" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"33"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA88"><span title="Page / location: 33"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>33<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup><sup about="#mwt1008" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nassar_1984_165-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nassar 1984"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Nassar_1984-165"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Nassar_1984-165" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 165;" id="mwA9A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9E">[165]</span></a></sup> rising to 9.4 years in 1995<sup about="#mwt1009" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kraft1998_164-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kraft1998"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kraft1998-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwA9I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9M">[164]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt999" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"33"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA9Q"><span title="Page / location: 33"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>33<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> and about 15 years in 2021.<link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements" about="#mwt1000" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"cn","href":"./Template:Cn"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"February 2023"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA9U"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_February_2023" about="#mwt1000"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt1000" id="mwA9Y"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2023)">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> Some cats have been reported as surviving into their 30s,<sup about="#mwt1013" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-30yo_166-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"30yo"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-30yo-166"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-30yo-166" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 166;" id="mwA9c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9g">[166]</span></a></sup> with the oldest known cat, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Creme_Puff_(cat)" title="Creme Puff (cat)" id="mwA9k">Creme Puff</a>, dying at a verified age of 38.<sup about="#mwt1017" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-G2010_167-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"G2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-G2010-167"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-G2010-167" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 167;" id="mwA9o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9s">[167]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA9w">Neutering increases life expectancy: one study found castrated male cats live twice as long as intact males, while spayed female cats live 62% longer than intact females.<sup about="#mwt1021" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kraft1998_164-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kraft1998"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kraft1998-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwA90"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA94">[164]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt1020" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"35"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA98"><span title="Page / location: 35"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>35<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Having a cat <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neutering" title="Neutering" id="mwA-A">neutered</a> confers health benefits, because castrated males cannot develop <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Testicular_cancer" title="Testicular cancer" id="mwA-E">testicular cancer</a>, spayed females cannot develop <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uterine_cancer" title="Uterine cancer" id="mwA-I">uterine</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ovarian_cancer" title="Ovarian cancer" id="mwA-M">ovarian cancer</a>, and both have a reduced risk of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammary_tumor" title="Mammary tumor" id="mwA-Q">mammary cancer</a>.<sup about="#mwt1026" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-spay-neuter_168-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"spay-neuter"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-spay-neuter-168"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-spay-neuter-168" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 168;" id="mwA-U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA-Y">[168]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="28" id="mwA-c"><h3 id="Disease">Disease</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1027" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"List of feline diseases"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA-g"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1027" id="mwA-k">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_feline_diseases" title="List of feline diseases">List of feline diseases</a></div>
<p id="mwA-o">About 250 heritable <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_disorder" title="Genetic disorder" id="mwA-s">genetic disorders</a> have been identified in cats, many similar to human <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Inborn_errors_of_metabolism" title="Inborn errors of metabolism" id="mwA-w">inborn errors of metabolism</a>.<sup about="#mwt1037" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-169" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-169"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-169" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 169;" id="mwA-0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA-4">[169]</span></a></sup> The high level of similarity among the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metabolism" title="Metabolism" id="mwA-8">metabolism</a> of mammals allows many of these feline diseases to be diagnosed using <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_testing" title="Genetic testing" id="mwA_A">genetic tests</a> that were originally developed for use in humans, as well as the use of cats as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_model" title="Animal model" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA_E">animal models</a> in the study of the human diseases.<sup about="#mwt1041" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-170" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-170"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-170" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 170;" id="mwA_I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_M">[170]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1045" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-171" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-171"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-171" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 171;" id="mwA_Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_U">[171]</span></a></sup> Diseases affecting domestic cats include acute infections, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parasitic_disease" title="Parasitic disease" id="mwA_Y">parasitic infestations</a>, injuries, and chronic diseases such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kidney_disease" title="Kidney disease" id="mwA_c">kidney disease</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thyroid_disease" title="Thyroid disease" id="mwA_g">thyroid disease</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arthritis" title="Arthritis" id="mwA_k">arthritis</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feline_vaccination" title="Feline vaccination" id="mwA_o">Vaccinations</a> are available for many infectious diseases, as are treatments to eliminate parasites such as worms, ticks, and fleas.<sup about="#mwt1049" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-172" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-172"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-172" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 172;" id="mwA_s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_w">[172]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="29" id="mwA_0"><h2 id="Ecology">Ecology</h2>
<section data-mw-section-id="30" id="mwA_4"><h3 id="Habitats">Habitats</h3>
<p id="mwA_8">The domestic cat is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cosmopolitan_species" title="Cosmopolitan species" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAA">cosmopolitan species</a> and occurs across much of the world.<sup about="#mwt1056" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lipinski_59-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lipinski"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Lipinski-59" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;" id="mwBAE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBAI">[59]</span></a></sup> It is adaptable and now present on all continents except <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antarctica" title="Antarctica" id="mwBAM">Antarctica</a>, and on 118 of the 131 main groups of islands, even on the isolated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kerguelen_Islands" title="Kerguelen Islands" id="mwBAQ">Kerguelen Islands</a>.<sup about="#mwt1060" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-173" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-173"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-173" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 173;" id="mwBAU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBAY">[173]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1064" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-174" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-174"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-174" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 174;" id="mwBAc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBAg">[174]</span></a></sup> Due to its ability to thrive in almost any terrestrial habitat, it is among the world's most <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Invasive_species" title="Invasive species" id="mwBAk">invasive species</a>.<sup about="#mwt1068" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-175" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-175"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-175" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 175;" id="mwBAo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBAs">[175]</span></a></sup> It lives on small islands with no human inhabitants.<sup about="#mwt1072" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-176" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-176"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-176" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 176;" id="mwBAw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBA0">[176]</span></a></sup> Feral cats can live in forests, grasslands, tundra, coastal areas, agricultural land, scrublands, urban areas, and wetlands.<sup about="#mwt1076" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ISSG_2006_177-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ISSG 2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ISSG_2006-177"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-ISSG_2006-177" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 177;" id="mwBA4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBA8">[177]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBBA">The unwantedness that leads to the domestic cat being treated as an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_predation_on_wildlife#Impact_by_location" title="Cat predation on wildlife" id="mwBBE">invasive species</a> is twofold. On one hand, as it is little altered from the wildcat, it can readily interbreed with the wildcat. This <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)" id="mwBBI">hybridization</a> poses a danger to the genetic distinctiveness of some wildcat populations, particularly in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scotland" title="Scotland" id="mwBBM">Scotland</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hungary" title="Hungary" id="mwBBQ">Hungary</a>, possibly also the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula" id="mwBBU">Iberian Peninsula</a>, and where protected natural areas are close to human-dominated landscapes, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kruger_National_Park" title="Kruger National Park" id="mwBBY">Kruger National Park</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./South_Africa" title="South Africa" id="mwBBc">South Africa</a>.<sup about="#mwt1083" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kruger_178-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kruger"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kruger-178"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Kruger-178" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 178;" id="mwBBg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBk">[178]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1087" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Oliveira_56-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Oliveira"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Oliveira-56"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Oliveira-56" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;" id="mwBBo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBs">[56]</span></a></sup> On the other hand, and perhaps more obviously, its introduction to places where no native felines are present contributes to the decline of native species.<sup about="#mwt1088" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-contr-ext_179-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"contr-ext"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-contr-ext-179" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 179;" id="mwBBw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBB0">[179]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="31" id="mwBB4"><h3 id="Ferality">Ferality</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1089" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Feral cat"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBB8"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1089" id="mwBCA">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feral_cat" title="Feral cat">Feral cat</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBCE"><a href="./File:Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBCI"><img resource="./File:Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg/170px-Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1436" data-file-height="1672" data-file-type="bitmap" height="198" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg/255px-Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg/340px-Feral_cat_Virginia_crop.jpg 2x" id="mwBCM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBCQ">Feral <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Farm_cat" title="Farm cat" id="mwBCU">farm cat</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBCY">Feral cats are domestic cats that were born in or have reverted to a wild state. They are unfamiliar with and wary of humans and roam freely in urban and rural areas.<sup about="#mwt1096" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Rochlitz_10-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Rochlitz"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Rochlitz-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" id="mwBCc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCg">[10]</span></a></sup> The numbers of feral cats is not known, but estimates of the United States feral population range from 25 to 60 million.<sup about="#mwt1097" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Rochlitz_10-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Rochlitz"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Rochlitz-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" id="mwBCk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCo">[10]</span></a></sup> Feral cats may live alone, but most are found in large <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feral_cat_colonies" title="Feral cat colonies" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBCs">colonies</a>, which occupy a specific territory and are usually associated with a source of food.<sup about="#mwt1101" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hsus-feral_180-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hsus-feral"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-hsus-feral-180"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-hsus-feral-180" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 180;" id="mwBCw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBC0">[180]</span></a></sup> Famous feral cat colonies are found in Rome around the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Colosseum" title="Colosseum" id="mwBC4">Colosseum</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Forum_Romanum" title="Forum Romanum" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBC8">Forum Romanum</a>, with cats at some of these sites being fed and given medical attention by volunteers.<sup about="#mwt1105" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-181" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-181"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-181" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 181;" id="mwBDA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBDE">[181]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBDI">Public attitudes toward feral cats vary widely, from seeing them as free-ranging pets to regarding them as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vermin" title="Vermin" id="mwBDM">vermin</a>.<sup about="#mwt1110" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-182" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-182"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-182" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 182;" id="mwBDQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBDU">[182]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBDY">Some feral cats can be successfully socialized and 're-tamed' for adoption; young cats, especially kittens<sup about="#mwt1115" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-183" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-183"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-183" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 183;" id="mwBDc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBDg">[183]</span></a></sup> and cats that have had prior experience and contact with humans are the most receptive to these efforts.</p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="32" id="mwBDk"><h3 id="Impact_on_wildlife">Impact on wildlife</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1116" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat predation on wildlife"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBDo"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1116" id="mwBDs">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_predation_on_wildlife" title="Cat predation on wildlife">Cat predation on wildlife</a></div>
<p id="mwBDw">On islands, birds can contribute as much as 60% of a cat's diet.<sup about="#mwt1128" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Fitzgerald_184-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Fitzgerald"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Fitzgerald-184"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Fitzgerald-184" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 184;" id="mwBD0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBD4">[184]</span></a></sup> In nearly all cases, the cat cannot be identified as the sole cause for reducing the numbers of island birds, and in some instances, eradication of cats has caused a "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesopredator_release" title="Mesopredator release" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBD8">mesopredator release</a>" effect;<sup about="#mwt1132" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-185" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-185"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-185" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 185;" id="mwBEA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEE">[185]</span></a></sup> where the suppression of top carnivores creates an abundance of smaller predators that cause a severe decline in their shared prey. Domestic cats are a contributing factor to the decline of many species, a factor that has ultimately led, in some cases, to extinction. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Turnagra_capensis" title="Turnagra capensis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBEI">The South Island piopio</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rallus_modestus" title="Rallus modestus" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBEM">Chatham rail</a>,<sup about="#mwt1133" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mead_1982_183–186_143-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mead 1982 183–186"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Mead_1982_183–186-143" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 143;" id="mwBEQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEU">[143]</span></a></sup> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./New_Zealand_merganser" title="New Zealand merganser" id="mwBEY">New Zealand merganser</a><sup about="#mwt1137" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-186" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-186"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-186" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 186;" id="mwBEc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEg">[186]</span></a></sup> are a few from a long list, with the most extreme case being the flightless <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lyall's_wren" title="Lyall's wren" id="mwBEk">Lyall's wren</a>, which was driven to extinction only a few years after its discovery.<sup about="#mwt1142" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-187" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-187"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-187" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 187;" id="mwBEo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEs">[187]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1146" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-188" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-188"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-188" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 188;" id="mwBEw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBE0">[188]</span></a></sup>
One feral cat in New Zealand killed 102 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./New_Zealand_lesser_short-tailed_bat" title="New Zealand lesser short-tailed bat" id="mwBE4">New Zealand lesser short-tailed bats</a> in seven days.<sup about="#mwt1152" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-189" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-189"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-189" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 189;" id="mwBE8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFA">[189]</span></a></sup> In the US, feral and free-ranging domestic cats kill an estimated 6.3 – 22.3<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBFE"> </span>billion mammals annually.<sup about="#mwt1153" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NC012913_141-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NC012913"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-NC012913-141" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 141;" id="mwBFI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFM">[141]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBFQ">In Australia, the impact of cats on mammal populations is even greater than the impact of habitat loss.<sup about="#mwt1160" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-190" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-190"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-190" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 190;" id="mwBFU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFY">[190]</span></a></sup> More than one million reptiles are killed by feral cats each day, representing 258 species.<sup about="#mwt1164" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-191" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-191"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-191" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 191;" id="mwBFc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBFg">[191]</span></a></sup> Cats have contributed to the extinction of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Navassa_curly-tailed_lizard" title="Navassa curly-tailed lizard" id="mwBFk">Navassa curly-tailed lizard</a> and <i id="mwBFo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chioninia_coctei" title="Chioninia coctei" id="mwBFs">Chioninia coctei</a>.</i><sup about="#mwt1168" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-contr-ext_179-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"contr-ext"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-contr-ext-179"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-contr-ext-179" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 179;" id="mwBFw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBF0">[179]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="33" id="mwBF4"><h2 id="Interaction_with_humans">Interaction with humans</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1169" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Human interaction with cats"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBF8"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1169" id="mwBGA">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_interaction_with_cats" title="Human interaction with cats">Human interaction with cats</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBGE"><a href="./File:Mainecoon-lap.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBGI"><img alt="A long-haired calico cat sat in the lap of a man who is sat cross-legged on the floor." resource="./File:Mainecoon-lap.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Mainecoon-lap.jpg/220px-Mainecoon-lap.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="554" data-file-height="593" data-file-type="bitmap" height="235" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Mainecoon-lap.jpg/330px-Mainecoon-lap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Mainecoon-lap.jpg/440px-Mainecoon-lap.jpg 2x" id="mwBGM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBGQ">A cat sleeping on a man's lap</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBGU">Cats are common <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pet" title="Pet" id="mwBGY">pets</a> throughout the world, and their worldwide population as of 2007 exceeded 500<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBGc"> </span>million.<sup about="#mwt1178" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_192-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NYT-192"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-NYT-192" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 192;" id="mwBGg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBGk">[192]</span></a></sup> Cats have been used for millennia to control rodents, notably <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Farm_cat" title="Farm cat" id="mwBGo">around grain stores</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ship's_cat" title="Ship's cat" id="mwBGs">aboard ships</a>, and both uses extend to the present day.<sup about="#mwt1182" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-193" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-193"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-193" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 193;" id="mwBGw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBG0">[193]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1186" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-194" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-194"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-194" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 194;" id="mwBG4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBG8">[194]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBHA">As well as being kept as pets, cats are also used in the international <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fur_trade" title="Fur trade" id="mwBHE">fur trade</a><sup about="#mwt1195" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-195" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-195"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-195" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 195;" id="mwBHI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHM">[195]</span></a></sup> and leather industries for making coats, hats, blankets, and stuffed toys;<sup about="#mwt1199" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-196" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-196"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-196" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 196;" id="mwBHQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHU">[196]</span></a></sup> and shoes, gloves, and musical instruments respectively<sup about="#mwt1203" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-197" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-197"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-197" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 197;" id="mwBHY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHc">[197]</span></a></sup> (about 24 cats are needed to make a cat-fur coat).<sup about="#mwt1207" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-198" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-198"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-198" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 198;" id="mwBHg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHk">[198]</span></a></sup> This use has been outlawed in the United States since 2000 and in the European Union (as well as the United Kingdom) since 2007.<sup about="#mwt1211" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-199" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-199"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-199" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 199;" id="mwBHo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBHs">[199]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBHw">Cat pelts have been used for superstitious purposes as part of the practice of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft" id="mwBH0">witchcraft</a>,<sup about="#mwt1217" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-200" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-200"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-200" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 200;" id="mwBH4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBH8">[200]</span></a></sup> and are still made into blankets in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Switzerland" title="Switzerland" id="mwBIA">Switzerland</a> as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Traditional_medicine" title="Traditional medicine" id="mwBIE">traditional medicine</a> thought to cure <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rheumatism" title="Rheumatism" id="mwBII">rheumatism</a>.<sup about="#mwt1221" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-201" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-201"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-201" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 201;" id="mwBIM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIQ">[201]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBIU">A few attempts to build a cat census have been made over the years, both through associations or national and international organizations (such as that of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Canadian_Federation_of_Humane_Societies" title="Canadian Federation of Humane Societies" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBIY">Canadian Federation of Humane Societies</a><sup about="#mwt1234" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Canadian_202-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Canadian"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Canadian-202"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Canadian-202" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 202;" id="mwBIc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIg">[202]</span></a></sup>) and over the Internet,<sup about="#mwt1238" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-catsbe_203-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"catsbe"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-catsbe-203"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-catsbe-203" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 203;" id="mwBIk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIo">[203]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1242" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SupremeCatCensus_204-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SupremeCatCensus"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-SupremeCatCensus-204"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-SupremeCatCensus-204" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 204;" id="mwBIs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIw">[204]</span></a></sup> but such a task does not seem simple to achieve. General estimates for the global population of domestic cats range widely from anywhere between 200 million to 600<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBI0"> </span>million.<sup about="#mwt1246" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-205" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-205"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-205" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwBI4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBI8">[205]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1250" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-206" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-206"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-206" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 206;" id="mwBJA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJE">[206]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1254" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-207" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-207"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-207" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 207;" id="mwBJI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJM">[207]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1258" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-208" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-208"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-208" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 208;" id="mwBJQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJU">[208]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1262" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-209" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-209"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-209" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 209;" id="mwBJY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJc">[209]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Walter_Chandoha" title="Walter Chandoha" id="mwBJg">Walter Chandoha</a> made his career photographing cats after his 1949 images of <i id="mwBJk">Loco</i>, an especially charming stray taken in, were published around the world. He is reported to have photographed 90,000 cats during his career and maintained an archive of 225,000 images that he drew from for publications during his lifetime.<sup about="#mwt1266" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-210" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-210"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-210" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 210;" id="mwBJo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJs">[210]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="34" id="mwBJw"><h3 id="Shows">Shows</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1267" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cat show"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBJ0"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1267" id="mwBJ4">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_show" title="Cat show">Cat show</a></div>
<p id="mwBJ8">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_show" title="Cat show" id="mwBKA">cat show</a> is a judged event in which the owners of cats compete to win titles in various cat-registering organizations by entering their cats to be judged after a breed standard.<sup about="#mwt1276" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-:0_211-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":":0"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-:0-211"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-:0-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwBKE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKI">[211]</span></a></sup> It is often required that a cat must be healthy and vaccinated in order to participate in a cat show.<sup about="#mwt1277" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-:0_211-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":":0"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-:0-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwBKM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKQ">[211]</span></a></sup> Both <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pedigree_(cat)" title="Pedigree (cat)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBKU">pedigreed</a> and non-<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purebred" title="Purebred" id="mwBKY">purebred</a> companion ("moggy") cats are admissible, although the rules differ depending on the organization. Competing cats are compared to the applicable breed standard, and assessed for temperament.<sup about="#mwt1278" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-:0_211-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":":0"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-:0-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwBKc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKg">[211]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="35" id="mwBKk"><h3 id="Infection">Infection</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1279" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Feline zoonosis"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBKo"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1279" id="mwBKs">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feline_zoonosis" title="Feline zoonosis">Feline zoonosis</a></div>
<p id="mwBKw">Cats can be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_predation_on_wildlife" title="Cat predation on wildlife" id="mwBK0">infected</a> or infested with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Virus" title="Virus" id="mwBK4">viruses</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pathogenic_bacteria" title="Pathogenic bacteria" id="mwBK8">bacteria</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fungus" title="Fungus" id="mwBLA">fungus</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protozoans" title="Protozoans" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBLE">protozoans</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arthropod" title="Arthropod" id="mwBLI">arthropods</a> or worms that can transmit diseases to humans.<sup about="#mwt1287" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Chomel2014_212-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Chomel2014"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Chomel2014-212" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwBLM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLQ">[212]</span></a></sup> In some cases, the cat exhibits no <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Symptoms" title="Symptoms" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBLU">symptoms</a> of the disease.<sup about="#mwt1291" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Ohio2016_213-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Ohio2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Ohio2016-213"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Ohio2016-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;" id="mwBLY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLc">[213]</span></a></sup> The same disease can then become evident in a human. The likelihood that a person will become diseased depends on the age and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Immunity_(medical)" title="Immunity (medical)" id="mwBLg">immune</a> status of the person. Humans who have cats living in their home or in close association are more likely to become infected. Others might also acquire infections from cat <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feces" title="Feces" id="mwBLk">feces</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parasite" title="Parasite" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBLo">parasites</a> exiting the cat's body.<sup about="#mwt1295" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Chomel2014_212-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Chomel2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Chomel2014-212"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Chomel2014-212" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwBLs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLw">[212]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1299" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-StullBrophy2015_214-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"StullBrophy2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-StullBrophy2015-214"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-StullBrophy2015-214" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;" id="mwBL0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBL4">[214]</span></a></sup> Some of the infections of most concern include <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Salmonella" title="Salmonella" id="mwBL8">salmonella</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat-scratch_disease" title="Cat-scratch disease" id="mwBMA">cat-scratch disease</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Toxoplasmosis" title="Toxoplasmosis" id="mwBME">toxoplasmosis</a>.<sup about="#mwt1300" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Ohio2016_213-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Ohio2016"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Ohio2016-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;" id="mwBMI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMM">[213]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="36" id="mwBMQ"><h3 id="History_and_mythology">History and mythology</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1301" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cultural depictions of cats"},"2":{"wt":"Cats in ancient Egypt"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBMU"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1301" id="mwBMY">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cultural_depictions_of_cats" title="Cultural depictions of cats">Cultural depictions of cats</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cats_in_ancient_Egypt" title="Cats in ancient Egypt">Cats in ancient Egypt</a></div>
<p id="mwBMc">In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt" id="mwBMg">ancient Egypt</a>, cats were <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_worship" title="Animal worship" id="mwBMk">worshipped</a>, and the goddess <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bastet" title="Bastet" id="mwBMo">Bastet</a> often depicted in cat form, sometimes taking on the war-like aspect of a lioness. The Greek historian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herodotus" title="Herodotus" id="mwBMs">Herodotus</a> reported that killing a cat was forbidden, and when a household cat died, the entire family mourned and shaved their eyebrows. Families took their dead cats to the sacred city of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bubastis" title="Bubastis" id="mwBMw">Bubastis</a>, where they were embalmed and buried in sacred repositories. Herodotus expressed astonishment at the domestic cats in Egypt, because he had only ever seen wildcats.<sup about="#mwt1308" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Malek1997_215-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Malek1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Malek1997-215"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Malek1997-215" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;" id="mwBM0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBM4">[215]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBM8">Ancient Greeks and Romans kept <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weasel" title="Weasel" id="mwBNA">weasels</a> as pets, which were seen as the ideal rodent-killers. The earliest unmistakable evidence of the Greeks having domestic cats comes from two coins from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Magna_Graecia" title="Magna Graecia" id="mwBNE">Magna Graecia</a> dating to the mid-fifth century BC showing Iokastos and Phalanthos, the legendary founders of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reggio_Calabria" title="Reggio Calabria" id="mwBNI">Rhegion</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taranto" title="Taranto" id="mwBNM">Taras</a> respectively, playing with their pet cats. The usual ancient Greek word for 'cat' was <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt1311" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"ailouros"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBNQ"><i lang="grc-Latn">ailouros</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt1311" id="mwBNU"/>, meaning 'thing with the waving tail'. Cats are rarely mentioned in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek_literature" title="Ancient Greek literature" id="mwBNY">ancient Greek literature</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aristotle" title="Aristotle" id="mwBNc">Aristotle</a> remarked in his <i id="mwBNg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_Animals" title="History of Animals" id="mwBNk">History of Animals</a></i> that "female cats are naturally <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Promiscuity" title="Promiscuity" id="mwBNo">lecherous</a>." The Greeks later <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Interpretatio_graeca" title="Interpretatio graeca" id="mwBNs">syncretized</a> their own goddess <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artemis" title="Artemis" id="mwBNw">Artemis</a> with the Egyptian goddess Bastet, adopting Bastet's associations with cats and ascribing them to Artemis. In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ovid" title="Ovid" id="mwBN0">Ovid</a>'s <i id="mwBN4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metamorphoses" title="Metamorphoses" id="mwBN8">Metamorphoses</a></i>, when the deities flee to Egypt and take animal forms, the goddess <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diana_(mythology)" title="Diana (mythology)" id="mwBOA">Diana</a> turns into a cat.<sup about="#mwt1315" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Engels2001_216-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Engels2001"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Engels2001-216"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Engels2001-216" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 216;" id="mwBOE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOI">[216]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1319" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-217" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-217"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 217;" id="mwBOM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOQ">[217]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBOU">Cats eventually displaced <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weasel" title="Weasel" id="mwBOY">weasels</a> as the pest control of choice because they were more pleasant to have around the house and were more enthusiastic hunters of mice. During the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages" id="mwBOc">Middle Ages</a>, many of Artemis's associations with cats were grafted onto the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus" id="mwBOg">Virgin Mary</a>. Cats are often shown in icons of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Annunciation" title="Annunciation" id="mwBOk">Annunciation</a> and of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holy_Family" title="Holy Family" id="mwBOo">Holy Family</a> and, according to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Folklore_of_Italy" title="Folklore of Italy" id="mwBOs">Italian folklore</a>, on the same night that Mary gave birth to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jesus" title="Jesus" id="mwBOw">Jesus</a>, a cat in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem" id="mwBO0">Bethlehem</a> gave birth to a kitten.<sup about="#mwt1325" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Beadle1977_218-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Beadle1977"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Beadle1977-218"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Beadle1977-218" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 218;" id="mwBO4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBO8">[218]</span></a></sup> Domestic cats were spread throughout much of the rest of the world during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery" id="mwBPA">Age of Discovery</a>, as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ship's_cat" title="Ship's cat" id="mwBPE">ships' cats</a> were carried on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sailing_ship" title="Sailing ship" id="mwBPI">sailing ships</a> to control shipboard rodents and as good-luck charms.<sup about="#mwt1326" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Faure2009_50-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Faure2009"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Faure2009-50" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwBPM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPQ">[50]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBPU">Several ancient religions believed cats are exalted souls, companions or guides for humans, that are all-knowing but mute so they cannot influence decisions made by humans. In Japan, the <span title="Japanese-language text" about="#mwt1334" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"ja-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"[[maneki neko]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBPY"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maneki_neko" title="Maneki neko" class="mw-redirect">maneki neko</a></i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Japanese-language_text" about="#mwt1334" id="mwBPc"/> cat is a symbol of good fortune.<sup about="#mwt1338" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-219" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-219"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-219" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 219;" id="mwBPg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPk">[219]</span></a></sup> In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Norse_mythology" title="Norse mythology" id="mwBPo">Norse mythology</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Freyja" title="Freyja" id="mwBPs">Freyja</a>, the goddess of love, beauty, and fertility, is depicted as riding a chariot drawn by cats.<sup about="#mwt1342" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-220" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-220"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-220" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 220;" id="mwBPw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBP0">[220]</span></a></sup> In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Legends_of_the_Jews" title="Legends of the Jews" id="mwBP4">Jewish legend</a>, the first cat was living in the house of the first man <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Adam" title="Adam" id="mwBP8">Adam</a> as a pet that got rid of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mice" title="Mice" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBQA">mice</a>. The cat was once partnering with the first dog before the latter broke an oath they had made which resulted in enmity between the descendants of these two animals. It is also written that neither cats nor <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Foxes" title="Foxes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBQE">foxes</a> are represented in the water, while every other animal has an incarnation species in the water.<sup about="#mwt1346" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Ginzberg_221-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Ginzberg"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Ginzberg-221"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Ginzberg-221" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 221;" id="mwBQI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQM">[221]</span></a></sup> Although no species are sacred in Islam, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Islam_and_cats" title="Islam and cats" id="mwBQQ">cats are revered by Muslims</a>. Some Western writers have stated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Muhammad" title="Muhammad" id="mwBQU">Muhammad</a> had a favorite cat, <i id="mwBQY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Muezza" title="Muezza" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBQc">Muezza</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt1350" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-222" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-222"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-222" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 222;" id="mwBQg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQk">[222]</span></a></sup> He is reported to have loved cats so much, "he would do without his cloak rather than disturb one that was sleeping on it".<sup about="#mwt1354" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Reeves_223-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Reeves"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Reeves-223"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Reeves-223" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 223;" id="mwBQo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQs">[223]</span></a></sup> The story has no origin in early Muslim writers, and seems to confuse a story of a later <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sufi" title="Sufi" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBQw">Sufi</a> saint, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ahmed_ar-Rifa'i" title="Ahmed ar-Rifa'i" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBQ0">Ahmed ar-Rifa'i</a>, centuries after Muhammad.<sup about="#mwt1358" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-224" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-224"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-224" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 224;" id="mwBQ4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQ8">[224]</span></a></sup> One of the companions of Muhammad was known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abu_Hurayrah" title="Abu Hurayrah" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBRA">Abu Hurayrah</a> ("father of the kitten"), in reference to his documented affection to cats.<sup about="#mwt1362" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-225" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-225"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-225" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 225;" id="mwBRE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRI">[225]</span></a></sup></p>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt1364" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"multiple image\n","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"direction":{"wt":"horizontal"},"align":{"wt":"center"},"image1":{"wt":"Louvre egyptologie 21.jpg"},"caption1":{"wt":"The ancient Egyptians [[Mummy|mummified]] dead cats out of respect in the same way that they mummified people&lt;ref name=\"Clutton-Brock1999\" />"},"image2":{"wt":"Cat birds MAN Napoli Inv9993.jpg"},"caption2":{"wt":"Ancient [[Roman mosaic]] of a cat killing a [[partridge]] from the [[House of the Faun]] in [[Pompeii]]"},"image3":{"wt":"PSM V37 D105 English tabby cat.jpg"},"caption3":{"wt":"A 19th-century drawing of a tabby cat"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBRM"/><div class="thumb tmulti tnone center" about="#mwt1364" id="mwBRQ"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:612px;max-width:612px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./Mummy" title="Mummy">mummified</a> dead cats out of respect in the same way that they mummified people<sup about="#mwt1368" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Clutton-Brock1999_4-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Clutton-Brock1999"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-Clutton-Brock1999-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 4;" id="mwBRU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRY">[4]</span></a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a data-file-type="bitmap" height="197" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Cat_birds_MAN_Napoli_Inv9993.jpg/300px-Cat_birds_MAN_Napoli_Inv9993.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Cat_birds_MAN_Napoli_Inv9993.jpg/400px-Cat_birds_MAN_Napoli_Inv9993.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Ancient <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Roman_mosaic" title="Roman mosaic">Roman mosaic</a> of a cat killing a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Partridge" title="Partridge">partridge</a> from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./House_of_the_Faun" title="House of the Faun">House of the Faun</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pompeii" title="Pompeii">Pompeii</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" resource="./File:PSM_V37_D105_English_tabby_cat.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/PSM_V37_D105_English_tabby_cat.jpg/200px-PSM_V37_D105_English_tabby_cat.jpg"
