//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/PSM_V37_D105_English_tabby_cat.jpg/400px-PSM_V37_D105_English_tabby_cat.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A 19th-century drawing of a tabby cat</div></div></div></div></div>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="37" id="mwBRc"><h3 id="Superstitions_and_rituals">Superstitions and rituals</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBRg"><a href="./File:Black_Cat_(7983739954).jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBRk"><img resource="./File:Black_Cat_(7983739954).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg/220px-Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg/330px-Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg/440px-Black_Cat_%287983739954%29.jpg 2x" id="mwBRo"/></a><figcaption id="mwBRs">Some cultures are superstitious about black cats, ascribing either good or bad luck to them.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBRw">Many cultures have negative <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Superstition" title="Superstition" id="mwBR0">superstitions</a> about cats. An example would be the belief that encountering a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Black_cat" title="Black cat" id="mwBR4">black cat</a> ("crossing one's path") leads to bad luck, or that cats are witches' <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Familiar_spirit" title="Familiar spirit" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBR8">familiars</a> used to augment a witch's powers and skills. The killing of cats in Medieval <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ypres" title="Ypres" id="mwBSA">Ypres</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Belgium" title="Belgium" id="mwBSE">Belgium</a>, is commemorated in the innocuous present-day <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kattenstoet" title="Kattenstoet" id="mwBSI">Kattenstoet</a> (cat parade).<sup about="#mwt1374" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-226" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-226"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-226" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 226;" id="mwBSM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSQ">[226]</span></a></sup> In mid-16th century France, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat-burning" title="Cat-burning" id="mwBSU">cats would be burnt alive</a> as a form of entertainment. According to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Norman_Davies" title="Norman Davies" id="mwBSY">Norman Davies</a>, the assembled people "shrieked with laughter as the animals, howling with pain, were singed, roasted, and finally <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carbonization" title="Carbonization" id="mwBSc">carbonized</a>".<sup about="#mwt1378" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-227" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-227"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-227" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 227;" id="mwBSg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSk">[227]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBSo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./James_Frazer" title="James Frazer" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBSs">James Frazer</a> wrote that "It was the custom to burn a basket, barrel, or sack full of live cats, which was hung from a tall mast in the midst of the bonfire; sometimes a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fox" title="Fox" id="mwBSw">fox</a> was burned. The people collected the embers and ashes of the fire and took them home, believing that they brought good luck. The French kings often witnessed these spectacles and even lit the bonfire with their own hands. In 1648 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Louis_XIV" title="Louis XIV" id="mwBS0">Louis XIV</a>, crowned with a wreath of roses and carrying a bunch of roses in his hand, kindled the fire, danced at it and partook of the banquet afterwards in the town hall. But this was the last occasion when a monarch presided at the midsummer bonfire in Paris. At <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metz" title="Metz" id="mwBS4">Metz</a> midsummer fires were lighted with great pomp on the esplanade, and a dozen cats, enclosed in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wicker" title="Wicker" id="mwBS8">wicker</a> cages, were burned alive in them, to the amusement of the people. Similarly, at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gap,_Hautes-Alpes" title="Gap, Hautes-Alpes" id="mwBTA">Gap</a>, in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Departments_of_France" title="Departments of France" id="mwBTE">department</a> of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hautes-Alpes" title="Hautes-Alpes" id="mwBTI">Hautes-Alpes</a>, cats used to be roasted over the midsummer bonfire."<sup about="#mwt1383" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-228" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-228"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-228" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 228;" id="mwBTM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTQ">[228]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBTU">According to a myth in many cultures, cats have multiple lives. In many countries, they are believed to have nine lives, but in Italy, Germany, Greece, Brazil and some Spanish-speaking regions, they are said to have seven lives,<sup about="#mwt1390" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-229" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-229"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-229" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;" id="mwBTY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTc">[229]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1394" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-230" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-230"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-230" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 230;" id="mwBTg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTk">[230]</span></a></sup> while in Arabic traditions, the number of lives is six.<sup about="#mwt1398" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-231" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-231"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-231" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 231;" id="mwBTo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTs">[231]</span></a></sup> An early mention of the myth can be found in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./John_Heywood" title="John Heywood" id="mwBTw">John Heywood</a>'s <i id="mwBT0">The Proverbs of John Heywood</i> (1546):</p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1399" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Blockquote\n","href":"./Template:Blockquote"},"params":{"text":{"wt":"Husband, ([[:wikt:quoth#Verb 2|quoth]] she), ye studie, be merrie now,&lt;br>And even as ye thinke now, so come to yow.&lt;br>Nay not so, (quoth he), for my thought to tell right,&lt;br>I thinke how you lay [[:wikt:groning#English|groning]], wife, all last night.&lt;br>Husband, &apos;&apos;a groning horse and a groning wife&apos;&apos;&lt;br>&apos;&apos;Never faile their master&apos;&apos;, (quoth she), for my life.&lt;br>No wife, &apos;&apos;a woman [[:wikt:hath#English|hath]] nine lives like a cat&apos;&apos;."},"author":{"wt":"Julian Sharman"},"source":{"wt":"&apos;&apos;[https://archive.org/details/proverbsofjohnhe00heywrich/page/104/mode/2up The Proverbs of John Heywood]&apos;&apos; (1874), p.104"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBT4">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote " about="#mwt1399" id="mwBT8"><p>Husband, (<a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quoth#Verb_2" title="wikt:quoth" class="extiw">quoth</a> she), ye studie, be merrie now,<br/>And even as ye thinke now, so come to yow.<br/>Nay not so, (quoth he), for my thought to tell right,<br/>I thinke how you lay <a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/groning#English" title="wikt:groning" class="extiw">groning</a>, wife, all last night.<br/>Husband, <i>a groning horse and a groning wife</i><br/><i>Never faile their master</i>, (quoth she), for my life.<br/>No wife, <i>a woman <a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hath#English" title="wikt:hath" class="extiw">hath</a> nine lives like a cat</i>.</p><div class="templatequotecite">—<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><cite>Julian Sharman, <i><a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://archive.org/details/proverbsofjohnhe00heywrich/page/104/mode/2up" class="external text">The Proverbs of John Heywood</a></i> (1874), p.104</cite></div></blockquote>

<p id="mwBUA">The myth is attributed to the natural suppleness and swiftness cats exhibit to escape life-threatening situations.<link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements" about="#mwt1403" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Citation needed","href":"./Template:Citation_needed"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"September 2020"},"reason":{"wt":"The origins and explanation of this myth need a credible source"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBUE"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_September_2020" about="#mwt1403"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt1403" id="mwBUI"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="The origins and explanation of this myth need a credible source (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> Also lending credence to this myth is the fact that falling cats often land on their feet, using an instinctive <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat_righting_reflex" title="Cat righting reflex" id="mwBUM">righting reflex</a> to twist their bodies around. Nonetheless, cats can still be injured or killed by a high fall.<sup about="#mwt1407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-232" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-232"}}'><a href="./Cat#cite_note-232" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 232;" id="mwBUQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBUU">[232]</span></a></sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;" about="#mwt1408" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"clear","href":"./Template:Clear"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBUY"></div>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="38" id="mwBUc"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="39" id="mwBUw"><h2 id="References">References</h2>

C.</a> (2005). <a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="http://www.departments.bucknell.edu/biology/resources/msw3/browse.asp?id=14000031" class="external text" id="mwBWs">"Species <i id="mwBWw">Felis catus</i>"</a>.
